name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 29 November 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted on 10 December 1948 in Paris. The declaration represented a turning point in the history of mankind, introducing principles and rights that are now indispensable points of reference. The declaration inspired our founding fathers, who had experienced the atrocities and the abyss to which contempt for human rights leads. Our Europe is founded on respect for the freedom and dignity of the individual, the guarantor of liberal democracy and the rule of law. These values are the essence of our European identity and have guaranteed seventy years of peace and mutual respect. The European Parliament has always been at the forefront of defending these values. For thirty years, with the Sakharov Prize, this Parliament has been paying tribute and supporting those who are fighting for human rights, often at a very high price. Five Sakharov Prize winners also received the Nobel Peace Prize and just today, in Oslo, Denis Mukwege and Nadia Murad received this prestigious award. All our congratulations go to them. I would also like to express our condolences for the death of Lyudmila Alexeyeva, a pioneer of the human rights movement in the former Soviet Union. This Parliament awarded it the Sakharov Prize in 2009 as a member of the Memorial Association. I would remind you that on Wednesday, in this House, we will award the Sakharov Prize 2019 to the Ukrainian filmmaker Oleg Sentsov, a symbol of the fight for the rights of political prisoners throughout the world. But today I would also like to mention the first human rights watchdogs, journalists, who risk their lives everywhere in the world for our freedom. My thoughts turn to Daphne Caruana Galizia, Ján Kuciak and Jamal Khashoggi, who were killed in the search for the truth, but also to all the journalists who are unjustly imprisoned in the world. (Applause)

name: Matt CARTHY

Considering that two of these political prisoners are former Members of this House and that their crimes amount to that of allowing people to vote to determine their own future, can I ask you, Mr President, when you intend to make a statement on this matter, knowing as you must do that the silence of EU leaders makes the EU institutions complicit in the Spanish Government’s disregard for international norms relating to democracy and human rights? name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, on 24 November, Selahattin Demirtas wrote to us from prison asking for support and solidarity. He has been in prison, along with 12 other colleagues and some 5,000 HDP activists, since 4 November 2016. On 20 November, the European Court of Human Rights called for his release, considering that his prolonged detention was contrary, in particular, to Article 18 of the European Convention and undermined pluralism and the free play of political debates.  Recep Erdogan immediately challenged the decision, deeming it non-binding, in defiance of the fact that Turkey is a founding member of the Council of Europe. Twenty-nine investigations are opened against Mr. Demirtas, and he faces up to 150 years in prison solely for remarks made at political meetings. In two days, a new trial will begin. That is why, in the light of the decision of the European Court of Human Rights, we would like a statement from the High Representative and a debate to show our support for Mr Selahattin Demirtas and his colleagues.

The animal was then transported on board to Lebanon with serious injuries. It's unclear if it ever made it there alive.  These are not incidents. This is daily practice. And it's still growing. Romania announced last week that it will immediately transport 200 000 sheep to the Middle East on a ship which has been banned from transporting animals in Australia due to repeated and serious animal suffering on board. name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy report on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Environment and Climate Action Programme (LIFE) and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1293/2013 (COM(2018)0385 – C8-0249/2018 – 2018/0209(COD)) (A8-0397/2018).

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you very much. We don’t have a lot of silence yet, but let me start by thanking all shadow rapporteurs for their wonderful cooperation; we had very smooth negotiations in order to find compromises. So let me start by thanking them for that.  Secondly, I would like to thank the European Commission for its strong proposal for the prolongment of the LIFE financial instrument, which is – let’s face it – the most successful financial instrument that we have in Europe. It is very effective, it’s very efficient, and it’s extremely relevant. It’s loved in Brussels, but also in the Member States by industry and by civil society. I think it’s an example of how European financial instruments should work. It plays a wonderful catalytic role to initiate, expand and accelerate sustainability, and its main success factor is that it’s quality—driven. It is not spoilt by politics. That sounds a bit strange in this political arena, but it’s quality—driven. As far as I’m concerned, as rapporteur – and I found quite some support for that among the shadow rapporteurs – we should continue to keep it quality—driven. Of course, even a successful programme can be improved, and there are two elements that I would like to highlight here. First of all, the original fund is far too small: we have EUR 5 billion. That’s why this Parliament already, in an earlier plenary resolution, asked for an increase to EUR 7 billion – very important.  The second point is that it should have more coherence with the other EU funds. LIFE is very successful, but too many other European funds are going against the interests of biodiversity, nature and the environment, and especially the strategic integrated projects under the LIFE programme play a very important role here.  I would like to highlight two more political elements that were also discussed in this House. The first is that this LIFE budget can only be relatively small if all other EU budget funds are not going against the interests of the environment. That is a very crucial point, also made in all the impact assessments by the Commission and in the introduction to the LIFE programme by the Commission. It can only have this limited amount of money if the other EU funds are not going against it, and it’s very important that we monitor that after the MFF has been improved at large.  The second, more political, debate is about national allocations. I’m very happy that we found a compromise among the shadows and that we did not fall into the trap of moving towards national allocations, but that we found a compromise on a bio-geographic balance, which means that we take the ecosystems in Europe as a basis and not our national borders. Finally, I would like to make some comments on amendments that have been tabled here in plenary. There is one EPP amendment that explicitly mentions the agricultural sector and forestry to include them even more strongly in the LIFE fund. I would like to emphasise that, under the current LIFE, agricultural projects are very much eligible. We currently have 136 projects ongoing, and so it’s not only superfluous; it’s also behaving a bit like the very hungry caterpillar. There are agricultural funds of EUR 400 billion already reserved, and this limited fund of EUR 5 billion should not be more strongly focused on the agricultural sector than it already is.  Finally, regarding the other amendment from the EPP on large carnivores: I know it’s a political debate and it’s worthwhile having that debate here, but putting it among the general objectives of the LIFE programme, which talks about climate, environment and biodiversity in general terms, and then adding large carnivores as equal to those general objectives doesn’t make a lot of sense to me. Let’s have that debate when we discuss the other, more individual, parts of it.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank, and to congratulate, the rapporteur, Mr Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy. I would like to thank, too, all the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) for their excellent report on the Commission’s proposal for establishing the next Programme for the Environment and Climate Action (LIFE), and also for proceeding with this report very quickly and with a lot of ambition. Speed and ambition in adopting the proposal for a LIFE Programme post—2020 are indeed necessary. The Commission has put forward ambitious yet realistic proposals for a modern EU budget, proposing clearer and simpler EU financial rules, which ensure that the Union budget delivers on the issues that matter to Europeans, such as the environment. Flexibility is a key feature of a modern European budget. It is therefore essential to maintain this flexibility in the LIFE programme in order to allow the Commission to respond to new and emerging issues in the future. Let me also emphasise that LIFE will continue to be entirely dedicated to supporting the EU’s environment and climate objectives, while broadening its scope to support the increased deployment of renewable energy and improved energy efficiency. We have proposed an increase of ambition through wider scope and also through volume for strategic integrated projects, which have an impressive catalytic effect. The new Clean Energy Transitions sub—programme will also enable stronger synergies in the implementation of environmental, climate and energy policies. However, I would like to stress that LIFE is not meant to solve all environmental and climate funding problems on its own. Rather, this instrument is a pivot at the heart of the Commission’s overall approach to ensuring that the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2021—2027 will support environment and climate across all of its instruments. Closing the gap between basic research and innovation, the new LIFE programme will support, across the European Union, the development and testing of improved methods to implement the EU’s environment and climate policy objectives. The new programme will ensure that those successful methods will subsequently be upstreamed and replicated across the Union. As a matter of fact, greater importance will be placed on EU added value. Let me be clear about this: the success of LIFE will depend on the EU added value of its projects, not on their distribution simply by Member State. That being said, the Commission will take care to pursue extended geographical distribution of the projects by supporting the network of national contact points responsible for facilitating the sharing of know-how and good practices. Finally, I would like to remind you about the importance of LIFE for nature and biodiversity. In addition to providing continued support for standard LIFE projects, the dedicated Nature and Biodiversity sub—programme under the new LIFE programme will include a new type of project, namely the strategic nature projects. These projects will specifically support national programmes to enhance the mainstreaming of nature and biodiversity into other policies and financing programmes, including through coordinated implementation of the priority action established pursuant to the Habitats Directive. Let me conclude by saying that I am keen to achieve a first-reading agreement before Parliament’s recess and I would like to reassure you that the Commission stands ready to play its role as an honest broker. Next week, I will discuss the LIFE programme at the Environment Council, where, hopefully, a partial general approach will be agreed. Such a timeline could allow trilogues to start as soon as January.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the BUDG Committee. – Mr President, concern for the climate and our environment has come to everyone's lips at the latest since the international climate panel published its report. It is clear that more action is needed. We have also seen recently that adapting to the situation and reducing emissions is by no means trouble-free. Our way of life needs to change, but it is very difficult. Combating climate change is cross-border work. Not only at EU level, but globally. It is therefore natural and absolutely essential that responsibility should be shared on the biggest shoulders. Climate and environmental work is the EU's core area of activity and life is the only EU funding programme that is fully earmarked for this work. Mr President, I am pleased that Parliament has already expressed its strong support for the continuation and strengthening of LIFE on several occasions and has wanted more money for this. However, it has to be acknowledged that the financial efforts available to the EU cannot solve the problems facing our environment, as the Commissioner has just said. It is therefore important that we use scarce resources sensibly. LIFE has been aimed at achieving a major re-impact even with a small amount of investment. This must continue to be the case. Finally, Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Gerbrandy, for his very good cooperation and all the shadow rapporteurs from the Committee on Budgets.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In its opinion on the LIFE programme, the Committee on Agriculture highlighted, inter alia, the following issues. The programme should contribute to the further transition to a resource-sustainable and energy-efficient low-carbon circular economy, inter alia through the transition to a highly energy-efficient and renewable energy system. References to sustainable agricultural and food systems, as well as to agriculture, horticulture, forestry and fisheries, should be included in the specific objectives of the programme. Furthermore, the programme must not interfere with the achievement of the objectives of other UNION rules and policies. The Programme should support better environmental and climate governance at all levels, including greater involvement of civil society, NGOs and local actors. As regards the structure of the programme, according to the Committee on Agriculture, the 'Environment' field should also cover sustainable agricultural practices such as soil biodiversity, agrobiological diversity, carbon capture, soil monitoring and environmental and water protection.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the LIFE Programme is one of the most emblematic programmes in the European Union and the only one which exclusively finances actions in the field of the environment. That is why it is always a priority for this Parliament. My colleague, Mr Dantin, spokesman for the PPE Group in this report cannot be here today and I, on your behalf, will mention the priorities for our political group. First, the protection of biodiversity and protected areas. In addition, in response to the challenges in several European regions in relation to the proper management of large carnivores, our group has tabled an additional amendment for this programme to finance this project. Second, support for farmers to adopt increasingly sustainable agricultural practices.  Thirdly, the support of the outermost regions in the LIFE Programme: given the great value of biodiversity in these regions, the Programme should include them expressly. And finally, administrative simplification. This issue has been claimed on a recurring basis by all life program beneficiaries.  Both the rapporteur, Mr Gerbrandy, and Mr Dantin have done a great job and in a very short period of time, so it is right to congratulate them. For my part, I would like to stress the importance of the Programme seeing its financial endowment increased and that it continue to support during the period 2021-2027 the protection of the Natura 2000 network and, in particular, natural ecosystems, species and priority habitats.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Regional Development. – Mr President, the European Union is and must remain a leader in the field of environmental and biodiversity protection and adaptation of European policies to climate change, which are very important for EU Member States and European citizens. One of the European Union's instruments in this regard is the LIFE programme. Its objective is to contribute to the transition to a clean, circular, energy-efficient, low-carbon and climate-resilient economy. This is done by promoting innovative environmental policy techniques. The LIFE programme contributes to the Union's objective of spending 25% of its overall budget on climate targets. However, the European Parliament has proposed to increase those amounts after 2020 to 30%, precisely in order to meet the proposed objectives. I believe it is important to give a strong signal to European citizens with a view to implementing the Paris Agreement and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the only programme specifically devoted to the environment and climate action, LIFE remains the European Union's main financial instrument for achieving environmental objectives. Significantly increasing the budget for the next 2021-2027 programming is therefore not only justified, but indispensable. LIFE plays a key role in the conservation of ecosystems, especially in relation to the Birds and Habitats Directives and through the management of Natura 2000. Biodiversity and healthy ecosystems are essential elements for growth, employment and the economy. It is therefore important to ensure, as indicated in my amendments, clear, quantitative and measurable objectives, with result indicators, monitoring tools and review and reporting mechanisms. The decarbonisation target of the Paris Agreement requires a rapid shift to a clean, low-emission energy strategy. A considerable proportion of the increase for the LIFE programme was therefore allocated to the "Transition to Clean Energy" sub-programme. In order to avoid overlaps with other programmes, it should be stressed that expenditure on LIFE should only be used to promote the development and dissemination of renewable energy and energy efficiency projects. I believe it is essential to recognise the importance of integrated projects that act as catalysts for the implementation of environmental or climate plans and strategies at regional, national or multi-regional level. In future, however, the scope will have to be broadened and the number of such projects increased, but these projects will have to be selected on the basis of merit. Each LIFE project must also be accompanied by a communication strategy in order to reach the target audience more effectively, provide key messages more closely linked to the objectives and ensure more structured coordination between the different actors. Among the innovations of the LIFE programme, I welcome the introduction of the 'Circular Economy and Quality of Life' sub-programme, which aims to support other aspects of EU environmental policy, in particular the transition to a circular economy, the sound and efficient management of natural resources and the promotion of good environmental governance.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which An old Indian proverb says: We did not inherit the earth from our fathers, but borrowed it from our children. As a Christian Member of Parliament, I see the preservation of creation as one of our important objectives. Across Europe, we can see the successful LIFE projects. In my region it is the nature reserve of Lake Galenbeck – a wonderful landscape and an enormously important place for migratory birds in Europe. Birds enjoy freedom of movement in the EU. Nature knows no national borders, neither migratory birds nor biotopes – and flora and fauna, by the way. Bee mortality is not a German problem, nor is it Hungarian or French: it is a global problem. We didn't have a German drought this year, we had it all over Europe. That is why these LIFE programmes are so important. They give back recreation spaces to nature. Europe will not become the Garden of Eden, but we will have a livable environment for ourselves and our children. The LIFE programme is a huge help.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, it is high on the European agenda that farmers should be given a fair price for their products. This week, for example, I am working on legislation to tackle unfair trade practices. What we are doing a lot is to ensure that legislation for farmers who come mainly from Brussels is workable and that farmers can get away with it. What I'm particularly concerned about is that we can start using more animal manure instead of fertilizer.  But one thing we seem to forget and I have a lot of concerns about that in recent years, that is the appreciation for the farmer and gardener. Because if you open the newspapers now, the farmer is very often used as a scapegoat for climate change, biodiversity loss, environmental impact and you name it. But we seem to forget what the farmers have already done, for example, and we conveniently assume that they do nothing.  But here's the numbers. Since 1990, the carbon footprint of milk has decreased by 32%, pork by 35%, poultry meat by 46%, eggs by 38%, veal by 50%, sugar by 41% and greenhouse horticulture uses 59% less energy. In the last three years, 15 000 hectares of agricultural land in the Netherlands have disappeared. In the same time, 11 000 hectares of nature have been added. The leaching of fertilisers has fallen dramatically in the last 20 years and there has been a ban on many hundreds of plant protection products, with no alternative available to some. Whichever agricultural system you use – whether conventional or organic – in the production of food, you always have an environmental impact and always take a look at nature. We must ensure that that impact is minimal. 80% of farmers in the Netherlands say they would like to achieve this.  Now we can do two things. One, seeing the farmer as a scapegoat and having no respect for him or two, see him as an important partner to further make agriculture more sustainable. I am pleased that this new legislation for the LIFE programme, which provides money for climate and the environment, seeks to take up that gauntlet and work with farmers for even more sustainable agriculture and horticulture.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/European United Left/European Green Left, I would like to thank everyone who has worked on this important issue for their good work. LIFE also needs a wide range of measures and funding from all other policy areas of our lives. Climate change, environmental problems and biodiversity loss do not ask for visas or national borders, and therefore cooperation and action across all borders are of enormous importance.  We have also seen the importance of inequalities between people and regions on this issue. It challenges us on a daily basis, and I therefore hope that Parliament, the Council and the Commission will take seriously the challenge of being able to come up with solutions that are also socially and regionally fair. Dialogue is needed, both for the Member States and for the citizens, so that together we can peacefully rise to the greatest challenge of our time.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Mr. Chairman, first I want to thank and congratulate our rapporteur Gerbrandy on an excellently done report, especially in the part concerning the budget increase for the LIFE programme. I think this is extremely important and I agree with CommissionerVella that, of course, there are other funds that can fund environmental protection and climate change, but this one should have at least one percent of the next budget to be able to provide those good things that are already recognized in the current LIFE programme.  Here I would like to point out that our cities and our regions have shown how usefully they use these funds and that 100% of financing through technical assistance and through capacity building certainly contributes to those goals that will help other funds be used in a much better and better way than before.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if there is one thing that Europe has done well, it is the LIFE programme. Since 1992, LIFE has co-financed over 4 500 projects, including 828 Italian projects, with a contribution of EUR 620 million. These projects have helped, for example, to make European citizens discover the Natura 2000 network and to protect biodiversity, which is still declining in Europe today. These projects have also helped to reduce environmental pollution and combat climate change. A Europe that, when it wants, knows how to serve its citizens and the common good. For Italy and the European Union, therefore, the LIFE programme is strategic and its continuation must therefore be supported. In the next seven years 2021-2027 LIFE must continue to support innovative actions to protect the environment and the climate, actions to be replicated on a large scale, to facilitate the transition to a society resilient to climate change, based on the circular economy and renewable energies, precisely that society that today we must try to defend in Katowice, Poland, during COP 24. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done. I particularly welcome the fact that it has identified, as further objectives of the programme, the fight against the degradation of ecosystems and the need to minimise the negative effects of chemicals. Finally, I agree with the decision to evaluate projects mainly on the basis of the quality criterion and to allocate more resources to the sub-programmes 'Nature and biodiversity' and 'Circular economy and quality of life'. I hope that the PPE's amendment that has been tabled will not pass, because I think and believe that it opens the door to further damage to biodiversity, particularly to large carnivores, because in reality we know very well what management of carnivores and large carnivores means, that is to say hunting, and I also hope that the ambition expressed by Parliament can be maintained, especially in negotiations with the Council.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, there is economic growth in Europe. Gross national product is increasing in almost every European Member State. But what does the ordinary citizen notice in their own wallet? Virtually nothing. Virtually nothing, Mr President, and this is also one of the reasons why the jellies movement is taking such a flight.  But where does that money go? I'll tell you. We're talking about climate today. There's a big bucket of money behind that, subsidy pots. Subsidy pots full of taxpayers' money available for large projects. And who benefits from these projects? In my experience not even the environment. It is the bankers and large multinationals, because they know very well how to empty these subsidy pots as professionally and quickly as possible. In the Netherlands, Mr President, next year an average Dutch family will pay an extra 300 euros to its energy bill. This shows once again that this EU is not built for European citizens. No, this EU is built for large companies and for bankers. Mr President, this EU is the opposite of Robin Hood. She steals from the poor and hands out to the rich.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, thank you very much. I would also like to thank our rapporteur Gerbrandy, but I have a bit of a different opinion than what he has just put forward here. We are now talking about LIFE and LIFE money. I hear from the Netherlands and also from other countries that the money for this will be difficult for projects. I also hear it from delegates from the Netherlands and I will be happy to refer them to you, because it needs to be simpler. I also think we should double-stroke. When it comes to money and agriculture, you say that this does not belong together, but the whole Committee on Agriculture and all the parties have supported me as shadow rapporteur.  Then I said, it's about the cycle. It is about low-emission agriculture. It is about farmers in Natura 2000 sites. It's about peatland areas. It's about the estate owners. It's about forestry when we look at CO2. So we can do a lot with it. We must also involve the citizens. So not against each other – that is often the case now – but with each other. And not as often happened in the Netherlands until now, that farmers are expropriated because they are in a beautiful nature reserve, when they have been there for hundreds of years.  I am also pleased that the Committee on Agriculture has fully supported me to do this, and I also hope that my amendment 79 – and you will never do it alone in this Parliament – will be further supported. When it comes to biodiversity and the great carnivores, you all know what Dantin said: it's part of it, it's flora and fauna. We're going from 5 billion to 7 billion. But Mr Gerbrandy, also an amendment – I was the author of it myself – on green and blue ecosystem services with new common agricultural policies. This allows us to make the double blow that farmers are happy to live in a nature reserve and involve the citizens in this.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: "blue card" question. I do not deny that there is a problem with large predators. I didn't say that either. But don't you think it's a bit weird when you describe the overall objectives of this LIFE fund – you're talking about climate in general, biodiversity in general, environment in general – that the EPP is adding large predators as the same category? Don't you think that's a little peculiar? Shouldn't that be raised in a completely different way?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" answer. – No, Mr Gerbrandy, that is clearly not the issue. Moreover, I would have preferred you to have asked me a question on the first point. But this second point is a very important point. Look at – when we talk about those big carnivores – the wolf. Look at how much burden it creates and how much money we need for it. These are points of discussion that are really important – look not only at the Netherlands, but also outside the Netherlands – throughout Europe. We need to pay attention to that. Certainly, as a spokesman for the Habitats Directive, we have also had large discussions with ministers from all over Europe from the intergroup to do more with this. Commissioner Vella knows better than anyone what I mean by this.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I believe that it is a very, very important issue that we are dealing with here today, and from then on I do not want to pour too much oil on the fire, but I would nevertheless point out that we had a very strange discussion in the Committee on Agriculture.  The opinion of the Committee on Agriculture has been prepared by a denier of man-made climate change. With the votes of the PPE-DE, Mr Agnew has been appointed to this end – since he is also in the room, I am referring to this explicitly. I believe that this allocation of the opinion was already a clear expression of the fact that we wanted to say that this issue is not so important, let us quietly push it further back. But we all cannot afford that. We need to do more for the environment.  Mr Gerbrandy, thank you very much for your report. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs has adopted a good opinion here, helping the report, so to speak, to get on the stockings, and I am very pleased about that. Two weeks ago, the international conference on biodiversity in Egypt ended. The climate conference in Poland is still under way. These conferences will address pressing issues of our lives here on this planet, and then discuss how we can prevent the further extinction of plants and animals, how we can get back into balance with the global climate.  The two issues are closely related, and we human beings are responsible for both problems – Mr Agnew. I want to make that clear here. We cannot shirk this responsibility. But we can also be part of this solution. We have the funds at our disposal, and I believe that the LIFE programme is a really good programme – Thank you, Commissioner! where we can do more for the environment and climate.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, investing in nature and biodiversity must be at the heart of an inclusive, sustainable and smart Europe. Today we have the opportunity to put the action to the floor, because the LIFE programme is the only programme specifically aimed at nature and climate action. It is essential that we support the Member States in the transition to a sustainable, circular and low-carbon society. This programme works and it brings European added value.  I was able to see this myself on a recent visit to the Kleine Nete Valley in Nijlen, the nature reserve in Flanders. The restoration of nature there was awarded a European prize. Investing in LIFE is crucial for nature, people and the economy. It is indeed about the health, well-being and prosperity of our children and our grandchildren. That is why we support the increase in the budget for the LIFE programme.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is very gratifying that Natura 2000 will be better equipped with finances in the future. We must support the Member States in complying with European rules here too, as can be seen, for example, in the deforestation of the last beech forests in Romania. However, it is particularly in the face of the Katowice climate conference – where we can see what coal dependence the entire economy, the entire city, has from this old fossil fuel – that it is clear that we must promote the development and innovation of renewable energy sources, and that we must not only support Poland in the phase-out of coal, but also provide proper support to all the regions of Europe here in the phase-out of coal. But if we all agree that this is such an important programme, why are we giving it just zero comma of any percentage of our budget? Then you agree with our amendment to increase the budget to 1% of the European budget – please, 1%! – if we all agree that this is so important. And in the direction of climate deniers or those who deny that we have man-made climate change, even though science is making very clear statements here, I would like to say to them: just because one repeats nonsense often, it is still nonsense.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, well you’re not going to like this are you, you lot sitting over there? It is such a shame that this LIFE budget is going to be wasted on a totally useless project trying to make farmers improve the world’s weather. What are the drivers of climate change? The main one, of course, is the activity of the cosmic rays, this atomised cosmic dust and, where our atmosphere condenses against it, cloud cover. What can the farmers do about these exploding stars? Nothing at all. What can the farmers do about the five different solar cycles whose cycle is well understood and that have caused the changes in our climate for over 2 000 years? Farmers can’t change the solar cycles. Farmers can’t change the gravitational pulls of other planets. Farmers certainly can’t change the ocean currents. We haven’t even got on to greenhouse gases yet, which are pretty trivial – the most important one of those for climate change is water vapour, and yet you never hear about that, and a very good thing too, because that is our cloud cover. They all talk about CO2. Yes, the levels have gone up. Why have they gone up? Because of the warming we had in the last part of the last century: the seas got warmer and released some CO2. CO2 is a consequence of global warming, it isn’t a cause of it. Then we’ve got methane that farmers produce in tiny, tiny quantities – it is a tiny, tiny gas. In any case, it breaks down to CO2 and water vapour. There’s no point in fiddling around trying to do anything with that. Then, of course, we’ve got nitrous oxide, the leguminous crops. We are wasting our time in trying to persuade farmers they can change the world’s weather. What could we be doing with this budget? We’ve got a serious problem worldwide called anti-microbial resistance. Farmers do have a part to play in trying to overcome this. We could use this LIFE budget to find ways of improving biosecurity on farms and then allocating grants to make the biosecurity a lot better. We could offer grants to farmers to cull their flocks when the only choice is to give them antibiotics. This would be a very good way of preventing antibiotic use. We could use this budget to research the breeding of harder, more resistant birds, instead of them requiring antibiotics. This is what we should be doing, not fooling around trying to persuade farmers they can be King Cnut.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the LIFE programme is one of the fundamental pillars for protecting our natural environment and advancing adaptation for climate change. Climate change, against which this week since CP.24 in Katowice we must conjure up and lead the changes needed to keep temperatures below the degree and a half. With the new LIFE we must improve this good tool that we already have; facilitate access to these funds at all levels of governance, from local authorities, which are the first window of access for citizens, to the Member States themselves, and with particular attention to the environments that will potentially be most affected by climate change, such as the Mediterranean islands; and, finally, simplify her access, as Mrs Schrijer-Pierik said.  In my constituency, the LIFE programme is having a vital role for the preservation of the Ebro Delta, as one of the programmes funded through these funds is aimed at the study of sediment transfer in the final stretch of the river. In the last century, the contributions of sludge to the delta have been greatly reduced by the construction of dams along the river, with the consequence, on the one hand, of its sinking, and on the other, the inlet of seawater, which directly affects the balance of this unique ecosystem that is a biosphere reserve.  I wanted to mention this example as a contribution of the LIFE program to the real improvement of our planet.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, the LIFE programme is a key instrument of the Union's policy for the protection of the environment, biodiversity and adaptation to climate change. Since 1992, it has financed almost 4 000 projects in the European Union, contributing more than €3 billion to environmental protection. The program leverages projects in the area of nature and biodiversity, circular economy and quality of life, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, transition to clean energy. LIFE has contributed to the Union's objective by affecting 25% of its resources to climate change adaptation and mitigation objectives. This effort must now be increased, as expressed in the European Parliament resolution on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027.  The proposal for financial duplication of the European Parliament's LIFE programme is meritorious and should be taken into account. Given the magnitude of the challenge, a strong and unambiguous cross-sectional response is required. The report under consideration today, and I welcome the rapporteur, makes a relevant contribution to the success of the programme, in particular by providing synergies between life and cohesion funds and policies, by defining specific rules for the financing of the outermost regions and in overseas countries and territories, by allowing the extension of the programme to third countries under certain conditions and by strengthening the contribution of regional and local authorities. At a time when the eyes of international public opinion are on COP24, taking place in Poland, we have an opportunity to take concrete steps in the implementation of the Paris Agreement, making the LIFE programme more financially robust. In Strasbourg, we have with this report another opportunity to send a signal to Katowice but also to the world, to all those who want to comply with the Paris Agreement.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We must ban fossil fuels and realise our zero vision of a carbon-free Europe that we Greens have been fighting for for for so long and which the European Commission is now finally supporting. We are also facing the great death of species. 60% of the earth's vertebrates have disappeared in 40 years. These are terrible and disastrous figures that show where our focus must be, namely on ensuring biodiversity and the habitats where animals still live. We need climate action now! More and more people want to live climate smart and awareness increases with each passing day. However, there is a great deal of uncertainty about what is effective and whether the contribution of the little man really matters. Then I really want to assure everyone here today. Your contribution is very important! About 25% of the population can change the direction of an entire society and the critical mass already exists. In my own country, Sweden, for example, about 24% of the population ranks the climate challenge as by far the most important issue of the future. I welcome this proposal for an improved and more ambitious LIFE programme. It is an important programme to increase the pace of transition in the EU.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, LIFE is actually the only financial instrument under the EU budget that is wholly dedicated to the environment, nature conservation and climate change, over and above national expenditure. While I would like to thank the team of rapporteurs for their good work, I would like to emphasise three things. Firstly, it is extremely important to increase LIFE funding. It is extremely important to use it as leverage for cohesion funds, especially for the circular economy at Member State level. And last but not least it is extremely important to emphasise the biodiversity aspect. We have very good experience with using the LIFE programmes for biodiversity and now, especially, when there has been a more than 60% decline between 1970 and 2014 in birds, fishes, mammals, amphibians and reptiles, we urgently need to increase LIFE funding and try to leverage Member States’ funding in these areas, and that also extends to large carnivores all over Europe. Thank you for the good work and hopefully the Commission can support and direct LIFE funding for biodiversity.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: – Mr President, according to experts, climate change will continue to be one of the major challenges we will face in the years to come. It's not a myth. Drought, heat waves and floods are becoming more and more common in all Union states. As a farmer, I can confirm once again that agriculture is one of the most exposed sectors to these changes, because it is dependent on weather conditions. In the context of the new Multiannual Financial Framework, I welcome the Commission's proposal to increase the LIFE programme fund by almost 60% for the period ahead, 2021 to 2027. I welcome addressing areas of vital importance to European citizens, such as nature, the environment and quality of life. Of the 142 projects supported by this fund and a total of EUR 430 million, 28 also successfully comprise the agricultural sector. More specifically, grants worth EUR 41 million support projects in areas for the cancellation and adaptation to climate change. I hope that this successful example will be an additional reason in encouraging access to funds through the LIFE programme and in the forthcoming financial year. I would also like to make a statement and I hope that my message will be received by the Commission. I want a settlement for farmers who have restrictions on the Natura 2000 sub-programme. I argue that they should be offered compensation for production losses. Our group has tabled an amendment to this effect and I ask all colleagues to support it.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, in the face of the climate emergency, in the face of the sixth wave of species extinction that the LIFE programme is supposed to contain, the European Union has decided to invest just 0.4% of its budget for the next seven years. That is three times less than the budget you decided to commit to create the European army and that is half what you will invest in nuclear research, for Euratom and ITER. This is to say how ecology is not a priority for you, when it calls instead for the mobilization of exceptional means to initiate ecological planning.  In the face of this urgency, we now call on you to apply the green rule rather than the golden rule. A European green rule, more virtuous for humanity, while you apply a golden rule to respond only to satisfaction and give satisfaction to the financial markets.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Indeed, we are dealing with the only green programme directly financed from the European Parliament's budget. That is why I am strongly in favour of strengthening it – financial reinforcement. According to the rapporteur, this increase should be around EUR 2 billion.  On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to one very important element: it is important that this whole programme has three serious pillars – on the one hand a good diagnosis, on the other hand, investment, and, thirdly, of course, an educational process. It seems to me that with the first and last element is already much better. However, as far as real investment is concerned, those investments that will change the situation are unfortunately too late. I am also in favour of increasing the tasks carried out for greening, for forestry, for the protection of this landscape, where greenery is most important.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Life programme is indeed important for the protection of the environment, in particular for supporting biodiversity, and has contributed to the development of Natura areas. However, Mr Vella, I would like to raise a serious point: I have repeatedly complained that in the area of South Karystia, on Mount Rachi, which is a Region of Niatura, there is now a violation and a violation of environmental legislation. Too many wind farms are being formed and they are not complying with the conditions. You yourself have replied that the Commission will refer Greece for a breach of the law in relation to the installation of wind turbines and wind farms. The same violation takes place in another area, in Agrapha, as well as in Monemvasia. But the question is when will you refer Greece? It's been a long time. Violations of the law continue and, when the case reaches court at some point, it will be too late. I want an answer, Mr Vella. When will European Union legislation finally be implemented in Greece?

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President, I support the report that strengthens the Life programme, including in the part where we are talking about more resources. I come from Slovenia, where we have more than 13 percent of our area protected as a protected area, in natural parks, regional, landscape, almost 38 percent of natura sites. And within these areas there are a large number of Life programmes that we are using to meet environmental goals. One of the most important things for Slovenia is the protection of pollinators, and World Bee Day is also part of our efforts. I also consider coexistence and awareness raising to be very important in these programmes. With these five, 10 billion, we can't save the environment. However, if we align the objectives with agricultural policy, energy policy, cohesion funds, we can do a great deal. And this is an important step in how to find within these areas the coexistence of agriculture, tourism, forestry activities and the creation of higher value-added products. Here I see opportunities for Life, that is, coexistence and awareness.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank everyone for their support and I hope that you too agree that the new LIFE programme will help us to promote sustainability, environment, nature, climate and clean energy transition objectives across the programmes of the 2021—2027 long—term budget. First, I would like to start with the issue of increased funding. The proposal for a LIFE regulation is part of this EU budget package, and altering the nature of the LIFE proposal will have a very direct impact on the entire EU budget which is the result of a delicate equilibrium among several EU funding programmes. And as I already mentioned, LIFE is not meant to solve all environmental and climate funding problems on its own. This instrument is to ensure that the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) will support the environment and climate across all its instruments. Also, let us not forget that the Commission has allocated a lot of money for the environment, in addition to the LIFE programme, and not to mention the amount of investment coming from individual Member States as well. I agree with the comments that were made that the LIFE objectives must also be mainstreamed in other policies and funds. Some MEPs mentioned agriculture and the CAP. The MFF already provides finance for the environment through the mainstreaming of policies into other environmental policies and other policies. It is in everyone’s interest to ensure that every single euro that is spent in the CAP, every single euro which is spent in the Structural Funds, for example, is contributing to nature and environmental policies. With regard to the CAP, I have full confidence that our farmers want to be part of the solution when it comes to protecting nature and the environment. I think Mr Gerbrandy also mentioned the broader geographical uptake and, even there I agree: we recognise the value of a broader geographical uptake of LIFE across Europe. We therefore need a new approach that will increase the number of high—quality applications coming from all corners of the EU. Under this new programme there will be financing addressing the specific capacity—building needs of the National Contact Points (NCPs) through network activities. Finally, I would like to remind our colleagues that the LIFE programme was very positively commented upon by the European Court of Auditors and it was mentioned as being very fit for purpose. Also, the ombudsman, in 2017, gave LIFE the Award for Good Administration. Perhaps one last comment – and here I want to be a little bit self—critical as well – there are already a good number of integrated projects related to the oceans. But I still feel there is perhaps the need to push more integrated LIFE projects towards the ocean environment, towards ocean biodiversity and towards ocean sustainability. I therefore look forward to working with the European Parliament and the Member States to ensure the timely adoption of this very important instrument. I reiterate the importance of concluding the interinstitutional negotiations early in 2019 in order to facilitate the adoption of the MFF at the earliest date possible. I would like to once again thank Mr Gerben—Jan Gerbrandy, all the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) for their excellent work, and I would like to thank all the speakers today for their contribution.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, many thanks for that – and thank you, Commissioner, for your warm words for the LIFE programme. I’ve learned a lot during the debate, and I think the most important element that I’ve learned is that the issues we disagree on are details in the overall LIFE programme. In general, we agree. We agree on quite a big increase of the budget, and we fully agree about the huge importance of this financial instrument. I sincerely hope that that will be reflected in tomorrow’s vote, and that we can start soon after tomorrow’s vote with the negotiations with the Council to finalise the whole process before the European elections. One final word: I emphasised in my opening remarks that the LIFE fund is only a small part of the total European budget. It is very crucial. Many colleagues have embraced the objectives of LIFE, and it’s important that these objectives are also reflected in all the other funds. This is just EUR 5 billion, hopefully EUR 7 billion. The other funds altogether are more than 1000 billion. So please take your thoughts about the importance of the environment, about climate policy and about biodiversity when you consider the other 95% of the EU budget.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 December 2018.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Claude Rolin on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the protection of workers at risk of carcinogens and mutagen in their work (COM(2017)0011 - C8-0010/2017 - 2017/0004 (COD)) (A8-0142/2018).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the European Union, the main cause of work-related deaths is cancer. Every year, 100,000 people die from exposure to carcinogens during their professional careers. Silent deaths, deaths that no one talks about, diseases that are not the subject of major prevention campaigns. That is to say the importance of the second revision of the directive on carcinogens and mutagens, which we are dealing with today. It is unacceptable that thousands of workers lose their lives to earn it. As such, I would like to thank the Commissioner for having the courage to launch the revision of this directive, which has been expected for more than ten years, to thank also the shadow rapporteurs and also the Council, the Presidency, which has been attentive to our work. A first phase has already been completed. Tomorrow, thanks to your approval, we will conclude a second stage which, with the first, will help save 100,000 lives in the Union in the next 50 years. This text sets exposure limits for six carcinogens. We wanted to be ambitious. With the mandate given to me by Parliament, I have defended the inclusion of diesel fumes faced by millions of workers. I could not mention all the sectors concerned, as there are: from construction, to the road or rail transport sector, to the mining sector or to the tunnel sector. But what is important today is that we always protect those who work better. The subject was sensitive, we negotiated at length, but the result is there. Together, we have succeeded in meeting this challenge: tomorrow, employees will be better protected, because we have included the fumes from diesel engines and we have set an exposure limit that will protect employees. The protection of workers must be strengthened even more. Science and technology are constantly evolving. We have undertaken a third revision of the directive, with the will to be completed before the end of the legislature. But beyond that, I again plead here in this Chamber for the next Commission to continue the work with the constant addition of substances to be controlled. We need a permanent review of this directive. Europe cannot stop in such a good way. The health of many workers depends on it. In this report, I also wanted to give back to the social partners the fundamental role that is theirs. To encourage stakeholders on the ground to be proactive, the Commission will publish the agreements on the OSHA Occupational Health and Safety Agency website. This is an opportunity for the social partners: to establish a real culture of prevention within companies, ahead of the legislative measures. I note with satisfaction that in October the chemical industry and the European trade unions, in a joint statement, asked the Commission to include toxic substances for reproduction in this directive. This demonstrates the willingness of the actors to move forward. As you will have understood, ladies and gentlemen, all these measures are not only essential to safeguard the health of employees wherever they are in Europe, but they are also beneficial for companies that care about those who make them work every day. By supporting this text tomorrow, it is the health of millions of workers that you will protect. By voting tomorrow, you're going to save thousands of lives.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear Members of Parliament, ever since the beginning of this mandate, the Commission and myself have given the highest attention to sound health and safety at the workplace, with clear rules that are enforceable and applied on the ground. We are delivering on our commitment to fight work-related cancer. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Claude Rolin, for his whole-hearted commitment to this file since the very beginning. Without his dedication, and the constructive support of the shadow rapporteurs and of all those involved, we would not be here today. The interinstitutional negotiations were not easy. For the Parliament, one of the key points was to include diesel engine exhaust emissions under the scope of the directive as well as a limit value in its Annex 3. Thanks to an open and transparent dialogue and the willingness of the Council to compromise in order to reach the common goal of strengthening workers’ protection, this point has been included in the text that you are adopting in this session. Dear Members of Parliament, together with the first amendment of the directive, for which I am grateful for the work undertaken by Ms Ulvskog, we already cover 21 substances. This will make a real difference on the ground and prevent more than 100 000 cancer deaths over the next 50 years. We are giving concrete meaning to Principle 10 of the European Pillar of Social Rights, which provides that every worker has the right to a healthy, safe and well-adapted work environment. Delivering on this principle indeed implies ensuring protection from carcinogens at work. The second amendment will send a good message to citizens and will set the regular updating process of the Carcinogens and Mutagens Directive on track for the years to come. There is still some work to do.
