name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Yes, it is a great thing we have managed to achieve to protect employees from dying from their jobs. It's an amazing task! We had a good proposal from the Commission first of all that would help us achieve the objective and we managed to improve this proposal so that it was superbly good, I would say. It is a happiness to be able to give up something that will mean a lot to many individual people. I would also like to thank the rapporteur who has worked on this work. He has had what we in Sweden call "ice in the stomach", that is, a calm face of a challenging situation. It was something that was required of all of us to finish this task. The limit values we are going to vote on this week are precisely the limit values recommended by researchers and by the social partners. I also think it is a demonstration that this is how we should legislate in the social field in the field of labour market. It is the parties who should be very involved. Without them, it won't be good. I hope that this will set an example for future legislative processes. As many of you know, we are also about to start tripartite negotiations on the third round of limit values for these lethal substances. I am convinced that we will be able to do so before the end of the parliamentary term. We've got a bloodied tooth. We want to make a difference. People shouldn't die from their jobs. They're going to live off their jobs.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr Rolin's report is a very valuable and important dossier. Protecting workers from exposure to carcinogens or mutagens at work is a moral and civilisational duty for employers and governments in the European Union. If, in the European Union, cancer is the leading cause of work-related deaths and around 90-100 000 people die each year in Europe, then taking further decisive action to prevent exposure to carcinogens and mutagers in the workplace becomes an urgent necessity. It is estimated that if we prudently and rationally set limits on exposure to carcinogens and mutagers at work, if we assess the risk properly scientifically and take optimal action, we can save up to 100,000 workers over the next 50 years. So there is something to fight for. The report rightly bends over to the protection of workers exposed in the workplace to reprotoxic substances, i.e. harmful to the reproduction of women and men, to which more than 1% of all european Union workers are exposed. This is between 2 and 3 million men and women. Even more so, the report is needed and has many benefits.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, the directive on the risks associated with exposure to carcinogenic or mutagenic substances is very important as it will provide an additional shield for workers. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Claude Rolin, for his work and his ability to listen. After a long work, diesel fumes were thus obtained to be included in European legislation, thus protecting 12 million workers from them. This process that we have undertaken must continue and be constantly open to workers' representatives and the precautionary principle must be given a permanent premium. This implies a re-evaluated occupational medicine, which must have the means to do prevention. The situation is so serious that we are told about 100,000 deaths a year from these carcinogens. Although not all the consequences are known, especially for children, as health scandals multiply. I would like to take this opportunity to point out many cases, in my country and in my region, of children born without arms in their hands, cases whose exact causes are not known and for which investigations should be carried out, including by the European institutions. In all things, we must choose life over competition and competitiveness, which too often prevail in our institutions.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have waited for 15 years. Finally, the Europe that protects is on track. From now on, workers will be better protected from exposure to carcinogenic and mutagenic substances in the workplace, because it is not work-related accidents, but cancer that is the leading cause of workplace deaths in Europe. One figure, just one: every hour in Europe, between 7 and 12 people die of cancer due to exposure to toxic substances in the workplace. From now on, eight new substances will be included in the law, and one that is not the least: diesel fumes. Everyone agrees to end diesel. Cities, states, many consumers want to get rid of it. Every time, it's to protect citizens from pollution and that's fine but it's even better if we don't forget the employees. Every year in Europe, 12 million employees are exposed to exhaust fumes, diesel exhaust fumes in the workplace. We are talking about people you see every day, working on public roads, driving tractors, trucks, working in toll booths.  So ladies and gentlemen, our goal is to take our responsibilities and finally, in this Parliament, we will understand that we must reconcile health and the environment. This is important, ladies and gentlemen, because we must protect workers in the same way as all other citizens, in order to move this social Europe forward in a concrete way, and I want to say this before you. I would also like to congratulate Mr Rolin on his ability to listen, because it was not won on diesel fumes. I also want to thank him for the fact that sometimes, when we want to go fast, we have moments of hanging, but we get there because, behind, we must not play with the health of the employees. Dying in the workplace must wake us up and we must open our eyes to this great responsibility.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr Rolin, tomorrow, with the agreement at first reading, we will also close the second part of the revision of this very important directive on the protection of workers against the risks arising from exposure to carcinogens or mutagens in the workplace. Once again, this Parliament has managed to be diligent and ambitious, always guaranteeing maximum protection for workers, facilitating small and micro-enterprises which, alas, often have limited financial, technical and human resources to fulfil the obligations imposed by this directive. I am also pleased that, in addition to the carcinogens initially included in the proposal, limit values have also been included for exhaust emissions from diesel engines and that a formal commitment has been made to assess, by the first quarter of 2019, the inclusion of reprotective substances. I would therefore like to thank Mr Rolin, the rapporteur, and the other Members with whom we have been working on the revision of this directive for over a year now, and I hope that for the third and final part too the same balance and ambition that has been demonstrated to date will be maintained.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, unfortunately, despite the enormous strides that science has made, cancer is the scourge of our time and one of the major causes of death worldwide. Workers exposed to carcinogens or mutagens in the workplace develop diseases such as cancer usually after the end of their working lives. In recent years, fortunately, important initiatives have been launched both at State and Union level to protect citizens and workers. Every day we discover new dangerous substances or, even worse, substances that we considered safe until now are finally proving harmful.  To date, however, no way has been found to create a completely safe working environment and we continue to pay all of us, especially patients, a very high price. It is therefore necessary for all of us to support any initiative or action aimed at addressing this risk. The report we are debating today is a step in the right direction, but it is by no means sufficient. Even stricter limits need to be established, and particular emphasis must be placed on information, protection and research in order to find suitable materials to replace the dangerous ones we are currently using.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, cancer is the leading cause of death in the world of work, far ahead of accidents. It was therefore our responsibility to act so that employment would never again be the cause of this destructive evil for workers and their families. The agreement reached between Parliament and the Council on the second revision of the European directive to reduce workers' exposure to harmful substances is therefore welcome. It is a protective agreement for employees but also pragmatic for companies.  But our action must not stop there because, every year, more than 100,000 Europeans die from professional cancer: larynx, liver, skin, leukemia, lungs, the list goes on. Beyond the legislative arsenal, other components need to be developed. First, we must not neglect the path of prevention and information for workers. This includes organising in-company training on the wearing of protective equipment such as masks. There is also a need to put in place programmes to support companies in the transition to less polluting systems.  Finally, we need to invest more energy and funds in research programs: they can enable us to develop alternative processes that are just as effective for business as they are harmless to men.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, this week we have the opportunity to better protect thousands, many thousands of car mechanics, road builders and construction workers from carcinogenic diesel fumes and other carcinogens in the workplace. Employees have the right to be well protected and not to be sick from work. Fortunately, this is reflected in this legislation.  If we vote in favour, we can prevent people who work with diesel-powered machines from getting cardiovascular disease, lung problems or cancer through work. If we vote in favour, we will avoid so much misery in so many families in Europe. Behind this misery, we can now put a stop to this legislation. As far as I am concerned, this is a great compliment to the rapporteur, to the shadow rapporteurs, but also to the Commission and the Council, that they have managed to conclude this deal so that more people can do their jobs with more pleasure and without harm to their health.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - The Chair, the legislative process is incomplete and flawed without assessing the effects of the rules. Very often, regulations concerning occupational safety are too complicated or insufficiently well-developed, leaving inspections with too much room for arbitrary interpretations. In some Member States, inspections use this space to disproportionately and often unnecessarily penalise employers and spread the anti-entrepreneurial climate. As regards dangerous carcinogens or mutagenic substances, these rules must absolutely protect workers. Workers' lives must not be in any way endangered in the workplace. In particular, I support that part of the report, which seeks specific measures for women of childbearing potential for the general objective of protecting the health of unborn babies and future generations. However, it is also worth considering the growing number of agents that affect infertility in men. To ensure a healthy future, we need both healthy women and healthy men.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, thank you very much to the rapporteur for this work. Currently 53% of annual deaths from work are due to exposure to carcinogens or mutagens. This second phase of the Directive takes a step forward by assigning exposure limit values to eight new carcinogens. However, implementation is one of the biggest challenges. Further controls, monitoring and dissuasive sanctions are needed to ensure the application of this standard and all those related to occupational safety and health. In this regard, I would like to recall the largest mercury poisoning accident in Europe, which affected 49 workers at the Asturian Zinc factory of the multinational Glencore. This November they went on hunger strike, six years later, with serious and degenerative consequences for their physical and mental health and still waiting for the company to take care of the health care they need and for administrations to recognize their disability. This, ladies and gentlemen, is happening in Europe.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is now of an absolute urgency to protect our workers from the carcinogens or mutagens that, we know, cause the diseases of tomorrow. Whether it is trichlorethylene, epichlorohydrine, ethylene dichloride or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon mixture containing benzopyrenes, the observation is the same: the setting of a practical limit value on the basis of the available information, scientific and technical data is, of course, going in the right direction. I agree with the rapporteur that the precautionary principle must be applied to the protection of workers' health. It is enough to rely on the 2004/37/EC Directive and Article 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It must be noted that exposure to these substances in a professional setting is also reminiscent of that of agricultural workers with pesticides. Exposure to pesticides is very real and, it seems, too often left out, perhaps because there are fewer and fewer farmers and rurality is often left out. We can see that all these problems stem from a common cause: short-term productivity, which is the alpha and omega of policies carried out under the European treaties, is too often imposed at the expense of health. This, ladies and gentlemen, cannot last any longer. The European imperative of competitiveness places our workers under the constant threat of offshoring. What for? Because they compete with workers in China, Southeast Asia or the Indian subcontinent whose working conditions often make them shudder. As the rapporteur himself points out, cancer remains the leading cause of work-related mortality within the European Union itself. So, I say, our role as elected officials is to protect the health of workers, the economy must be at the service of man and not the other way around.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, some additions or reductions in the prices of carcinogens to the relevant list of the directive you are bringing are patchy and you are even referring to their implementation from 2023 to 2025. The proposal for a directive speaks not of substantial and complete but of minimum protection – that is to say for the eyes of the world – also defined by the unique criteria you recognise, the criteria of competitiveness, cost and benefit, all of which contribute to the profitability of capital – all with private companies that you put in place to do the checks and are paid by employers whom they will otherwise control , i.e. those who break the limits to serve their profits. You literally have the wolf guard the sheep.  The measures are far behind the full exploitation of scientific knowledge and technological achievements and remain great untapped prevention possibilities. The struggle of workers for real protection against occupational diseases and all kinds of harmful factors in the workplace is very necessary and conflicts with the criterion of capitalist profit.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, people have the right to a safe and healthy working environment. I would therefore particularly like to thank the Commissioner and the rapporteur for the unyying, will and also courageous work they have done to reduce carcinofective substances in the working environment. I also think that adding diesel gases to this list has been a very positive thing to do. The well-being, health and life of 100,000 people in the workplace every year is no small matter. However, this is the never-ending battle we are facing, due, among other things, to new chemical compounds and compound interactions that we are not yet familiar with. That is why I would warmly support the rapporteur's proposal that the new Commission should start preparing a revision of this legislation and that a review of the legislation should be taken as a general practice, for example every five years, allowing us to remain at the forefront of development and prevent new dangerous compounds in the workplace and, through new information, also to eliminate old ones whose risks are known.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, cancer is the leading cause of death in the workplace in the European Union, at the forefront of lung cancer. Nevertheless, the Commission has so far incomprehensibly refused to include exhaust gases from diesel engines in the scope of the so-called Cancer Directive. A large majority in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs set an exhaust limit value of 0.0 mg/m3 on 27 March this year; this also follows the German limit value. Some 3.6 million workers in Europe, particularly in warehouses, mining or freight transport, will be better protected from diesel emissions in the future. Good job! This is practical European legislation to protect workers. This will continue and must be constantly renewed.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Madam President, cancer in the workplace remains one of the key challenges in the fight against cancer and requires the most deaths among workplace-related diseases. I therefore welcome my colleague Rolin's report, also on behalf of the Working Party on Cancer in the European Parliament. To be more successful, we need to improve the legislation, and that is what we are doing. Any improvement in the directive can contribute to fewer cancers and fewer deaths from it. It is crucial that the legislation is clear, that the requirements are very precise and that they are, of course, implemented at all levels of companies or in large, small and medium-sized enterprises. And I think it is necessary to insist on the requirements already laid down by the basic directive with regard to the elimination and replacement of substances, as well as to limit values. I am pleased that we are adding limit values for seven additional carcinogenic or mutagenic substances, and I am convinced that the revised directive is a step towards greater protection for workers. However, I agree with the rapporteur that implementations and audits need to be paid constant attention, that I am not talking about diesel, which others have already spoken about, because my time has passed.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Good news for workers in Europe: diesel exhaust gases are limited in the workplace. Diesel is not good in the air and certainly not in the lungs of workers. And that's why it's really good news. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, who, as a trade unionist, knows exactly how important it is to involve the social partners so that the health of workers in the workplace is adequately protected. 3.6 million workers no longer have to be helplessly exposed to these exhaust gases. And that's really good news. In the 21st century, it should no longer be the case that people die at work as a result of exhaust fumes. Cancer is tricky, you don't see it. Above all, it also shows how important it is for us in the European Parliament to stick to it – often patiently for many years with the Commissioner, who has stayed the same here – and finally bring this issue to a good end.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to congratulate My colleague Rolin, because we will undoubtedly see further progress in the fight against cancer. But since you are a trade unionist, on this occasion I would like to repmonies you about three things that I miss a little bit. Firstly, I would like to draw attention to those people who are no longer working but who have worked with these measures, which we consider harmful today. It is worth extending them to a medical diagnosis, first of all, in order to make up for this lost time. These people have worked for a very long time in these conditions requiring medical care and greater awareness. The second thing – it is necessary to improve the awareness, knowledge, skills of health and safety services, that is, those that prepare employees to pursue a certain profession under certain conditions. Unfortunately, in some countries, we have the 1950s or the 1960s. And the last thing – universal education. If we are talking about cancer that is caused or contributed to by the use of certain oils or means, please note how many workers develop skin cancer as a result of working in the sun without protective clothing. Today, this is a very important problem in southern countries all the time.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done A heartfelt thank you for presenting this new, extended protection of workers. We talk so often about the fact that cancer can, of course, also be partly justified by our own behaviours: too little exercise, stay in the wrong regions. But the workplace is one where we need the protection of the employer, the protection of European legislation, because here no one voluntarily exposes themselves to these exhaust gases, these carcinogens. In other words, we need common rules here. This is another step in the right direction. It is now important, of course, not only to have the best legislation. Because, as is very often the case at European level, it fails or succeeds through proper implementation and, in retrospect, also through control. I therefore call not only on us MePs to agree to this, but also on individual employers employers to follow the truly law-abiding implementation of this proposal, and for the Member States to carry out appropriate checks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, cancer literally reaps. 53% of mortality actually comes from exposure to carcinogens and mutagenic agents. This is largely done in business, because after the Chineseization of wages we now also have the Chineseization of working conditions: no protection. I therefore think it is necessary to take measures to protect the workers themselves, who are exposed either because they are in contact with the skin, or by eye contact, by ingestion, or by inhalation and exposed to these carcinogens. Much more exposed to diesel exhaust. We must therefore have preventive measures, that is the most important thing. Secondly, protection measures and equipment to protect workers and penalties for offenders, because that is the only way they will actually be forced to comply with the requirements of the directive.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, there are many deaths from cancers due to the exposure of workers to mutagenic and carcinogenic chemical agents in the workplace. That is why this unacceptable situation must be addressed. It is true that both employers and the Member States and the European Union as a whole are making efforts to limit workers' exposure to factors such as diesel engine exhaust, old and new, polycyclic hydrocarbons, as well as aromatics, which are absorbed by the skin. They also set some minimum thresholds which should not be exceeded with regard to workers' exposure. But these are half-measures; other measures must be taken, such as the manufacture of new engines that do not produce fuel with polluting substances, and above all legislation must be laid down in order to intervene in the State and punish those entrepreneurs who do not care about the protection of their workers.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I’m very glad that Parliament is debating improving regulations around carcinogenic substances. It’s of vital importance that workplaces are safe and that people have protection from deadly chemicals. In my constituency, the Greater Manchester Hazards Centre has researched and campaigned for the reduction and removal of carcinogenic substances. They highlight the tragedy at the heart of this issue. Between 8% and 16% of cancer in European citizens is related to workplace exposure, and these cases of cancer are preventable. The GM Hazards Centre also explains that women and low—paid workers are at higher risk of exposure to carcinogenic substances. As women are more likely to do work in cleaning, fragrances and cosmetics, they are exposed to more deadly chemicals. This highlights the gender imbalance in the workplace. We must also not forget the unregulated work that is done in Europe. Hidden and exploited workers are exposed daily to hazards in the workplace, and the EU must reach out proactively to end illegal employment practices and ensure all workers are safe from hazards.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, once more I would like to thank the co-legislators for finding an agreement on a Commission proposal that will help save many workers’ lives. However, this is not the end of our initiatives to fight occupational cancer. The third amendment to the Directive, addressing five additional important substances and groups of substances, is on the way, and in that regard, I congratulate Parliament on the adoption of Ms Agea’s report on the third batch. The interinstitutional negotiations can start now, which should make it possible for this further modification of the directive to be adopted before the end of the current term. As I said before, I am convinced that the three amendments which I was allowed to initiate in this Commission have now set on track a regular process of updating the Carcinogens and Mutagens Directive. That is a great achievement, for which I particularly wish to thank the three rapporteurs, Claude Rolin, Marita Ulvskog and Laura Agea, as well as the shadow rapporteurs. Madam President, honourable Members, before I conclude let me also tell you that my staff have started preparatory work on the inclusion of occupational exposure limit values for three additional priority substances, and, of course, we are continuing to develop this legislation on the basis of scientific evidence and in close cooperation with the social partners. I am sure you will agree with me that this is Europe at its best – a Europe that protects. Thank you for all your work.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, the unanimous vision we are hearing here is a strong political message, which shows the importance of the health and safety of workers in Europe for the European Parliament. A lot has been talked about, but for me, in terms of health and safety, alpha and omega, it is prevention, information and awareness. It is also the role of occupational physicians, who have an essential role in the company and who must pay attention to the gendered nature of cancer, because women and men are not affected in the same way.  Control is essential, follow-up is essential, we talked about it, it is written in the first part, THE CMD1. We must continue to mobilize the actors on the ground, especially the social partners. If we have been able to do this work, it is thanks to the Commission, it is thanks to the attitude of the Council, but it is mainly because with Laura and Marita, together with the shadow rapporteurs, we have been able to form a team, a team mobilized on this fundamental issue, and it works when we can do it that way. Commissioner, it is clear that we will have to continue to work to get this permanent revision of this directive, to ensure that the protection is very concrete. I am indeed, I was and still am a trade unionist at heart and quite a few of my unionist friends asked me, when I put myself on a list for the European elections: Claude what are you going to do there? Well, I will continue my job to defend salaried workers, to defend life in companies, and I think that this, what we will vote tomorrow, makes sense.  And if one day my grandchildren ask me: what have you been doing in the European Parliament? Well, I can tell them that with you I have helped to give concrete meaning to a Europe that protects, protects health and saves lives.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 December 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Cancer still poses one of the most significant health risks for workers in the EU. Unfortunately, it is the most common cause of occupational-related deaths. Our response must therefore be to prevent workers from being exposed to chemicals that may cause it. The limitations and tightening of the limit values concern a number of cancer-causing substances. However, a simple example is also the limitation of workers' exposure to diesel engine exhaust, which are also highly carcinogenic to humans. Workers' health must be protected throughout their working lives, and great emphasis must be placed, in particular, on improving prevention. In addition to the employees themselves, this is also beneficial for employers, the European economy as a whole, or the reduction of the cost of the necessary healthcare.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I remember very well how we launched this food basic regulation at the time. There have been difficulties with our food, more and more food scandals. And we needed something that would give us and our citizens more security. That is why we have set up the European Food Safety Authority. The work of this authority has been very successful. Our food in the European Union is considered to be the safest in the world. However, EFSA has not yet had to comply with the same transparency rules as other agencies, such as the Agency for Medical Devices or the Chemicals Agency. The Commission has proposed, driven by the European Citizens' Initiative against glyphosate, to change this now and to harmonise these rules. What the Commission ultimately proposed, however, was not approximation, but was much, much stricter rules for EFSA than the other agencies have. (The President interrupted because of a lack of English interpretation) However, the Commission has now proposed new rules for the European Food Safety Authority, which go much further than the transparency rules that the other agencies must comply with. The other agencies publish the applications submitted and the studies on which they are based, at the moment when they publish their opinion on the application. EFSA is now supposed to do things very differently, according to the Commission. It is intended to publish the application and the underlying studies directly at the beginning of the process, when the application has been submitted. When I read this, I thought: is the Commission so naive, or is it wanted? Does this have something to do with election campaigns? We have all been in pre-election mode for months, and the Commissioner seems to me to be in the pre-election campaign as well. Surely we cannot force an applicant to present his application, his new idea, his innovation to the world public via EFSA's website. It is not acceptable for an applicant to be indirectly forced to make his/her documents available publicly on the internet worldwide by submitting an application for authorisation of his new innovative product to EFSA. This encourages piracy of ideas! EFSA's authorisation procedures take a very, very long time, up to 55 months. After all, everyone in the world – competitors in third countries – has the good opportunity to check EFSA's homepage every day to see what new innovations are in Europe, copy-paste, and they are already starting to copy this product while the authorisation process is still in progress in Europe. And the third-country competitor has the opportunity to bring a product that it has stolen to the world market, and can probably offer it much cheaper than the European could ever. The European product is dead, and the European producer is lagting behind. That's wrong! That is why I am suggesting something quite different that brings at least as much transparency. I do not understand why the Commission does not think that this should be supported. I propose a three-stage procedure. First of all, EFSA examines the application and the underlying studies, then publishes the draft of its scientific opinion and at the same time the application information and the underlying studies. And then the second stage begins: a consultation phase in which the public, the interested public, the application and the underlying studies can put the matter through their paces. We can talk about the duration of the consultation period, there is no question about that. However, it is only after this consultation phase that EFSA, as I propose, should publish its final opinion and then be able to take into account the outcome of this public consultation. I think that is the right procedure. EFSA is already doing this on its own, and why should we not make this system compulsory? I would like to point out that, for example, in the case of acrylamide, EFSA has once again amended its final opinion after such a public consultation. So that is possible, and it has even an advantage for the public: you already have EFSA's assessment of this request and the underlying studies as a means of dealing with it. I therefore ask for my request to support my request. One final word: if the Commission proposal gets through, we will have much, much less transparency than we have today. In that case, no applicant will apply for authorisation of his product in Europe. Then if the manufacturers go directly abroad with their innovations, and then we will no longer have access to the application documents. That is not what we want! So, I ask for your support for my proposal.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much indeed for the opportunity to speak on this important proposal. Whenever we talk about our health and that of our children, people are absolutely right to ask for the highest standards of transparency and scrutiny. In recent years, European citizens have expressed such a clear demand for more transparency in the way that risk assessments are conducted, and I have been listening carefully to them and have been active on this issue since the beginning of my term of office. Some of you in this House have expressed the same legitimate demand. In fact, when the European Parliament voted its resolution on glyphosate one year ago, it stressed the following: that the European Union’s authorisation procedure, including the scientific evaluation of substances, should be based only on published studies. The European Citizens’ Initiative in relation to glyphosate also asked the Commission to base its decision on published studies, and the findings of the recent ‘fitness check’ on the General Food Law Regulation confirmed this priority. Today’s debate is a significant stepping stone on the way to meeting these expectations and to showing that the EU can deliver on our demands, on your demands and on citizens’ demands. Allow me to draw your attention to the main features of the Commission’s ambitious proposal. I would like to explain briefly how we have pursued the objectives of reinforcing transparency and trust. I believe it is through greater transparency that we will increase citizens’ confidence in the risk assessment system. The new legislation will thus contribute to increasing the legitimacy of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and of the Commission’s decisions when it accepts or rejects requests for approval. With this goal in mind, the Commission has proposed proactive public disclosure of all safety—related data – let me repeat, safety—related data – supporting applications for authorisation, and we have proposed that this be done early in the risk assessment process. Early disclosure is essential to ensure maximum transparency and public scrutiny in an effective way, while maintaining a timely and effective risk management process. Of course, transparency can also help us to avoid potential bias in science. It is crucial to restore trust in the EU’s evidence—based food safety system and trust in science. Let me insist on one important point. Postponing transparency until the opinion is published would, as we know from practice today, risk feeding suspicion and controversies. It would not permit a real scientific debate between different views, but would lead to more political controversies – and we have had too many of those recently. As long as the principle of early disclosure is retained, however, its exact timing could be the subject of further consideration. For example, it could coincide with the moment the underlying application is found admissible. This disclosure of studies is also closely linked with two other measures in our proposal: first, the public consultation of submitted studies; and, second, the disclosure of the relevant information in the Union register of commissioned studies. These measures will ensure that EFSA has at its disposal the broadest relevant scientific evidence possible before it drafts its scientific opinion. And, of course, any rights stemming from the Access to Documents Regulation and the Aarhus Convention remain intact and will continue to apply. At the same time, I am aware of concerns in relation to the protection of innovation, but I want to reassure you that, when we prepared this proposal, we also had in mind the need to maintain the European Union’s high food safety standards together with the competitiveness of the EU food and feed sector. There is no controversy as between food safety standards and competitiveness, and that is why the proposal sets out safeguards for the protection of justifiable, confidential information. It includes a closed positive list of items that may be claimed as confidential. Confidentiality can be claimed if the applicant can prove that public disclosure of such information would significantly harm its competitive position. At the same time, the proposal respects existing intellectual property rights, data exclusivity rights and rules on the protection of personal data. These are recognised as key to stimulating innovation, and for the worldwide recognition of EU product safety. Furthermore, to assist applicants – most importantly, small and medium-sized enterprises – we have introduced the possibility of EFSA providing pre—submission advice. This advice will facilitate a better understanding of the application process and will make life easier for innovators in Europe. Finally, the proposal also provides for the possibility of commissioning additional studies for verification purposes. This may be done in exceptional circumstances, for example in the event of public controversy or scientific divergence about a product. Further to the provisions on transparency, and to ensure the long—term sustainability of EFSA’s high level of independent expertise, it is proposed that Member States will be represented on the EFSA Management Board. Similarly, and without jeopardising EFSA’s independence, there is provision for more active involvement by Member States in ensuring the presence of experts on EFSA’s scientific panels. It has also been recognised that there is a need to improve on our communication of risk. It is important that strong, clear messaging on risks is available to our citizens. To this end, the proposal lays the foundations for a comprehensive and effective risk-communication strategy to ensure that, whether the message comes from the Commission, EFSA or Member States, it will be clear, comprehensive and consistent. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission are all responsible for maintaining and reinforcing an EU food safety system based on scientific assessments. Transparency and risk assessment are therefore a shared duty for all of us. With this proposal, we are, more than ever, playing our part. I would like to thank all those involved, including the rapporteur, Ms Sommer, and the shadow rapporteur as well as the rapporteurs for opinion, for their active commitment so far – and, I hope, for their continued engagement and dedication in advancing with the Commission proposal and defending transparency. Who can be against transparency in science? No one. I look forward to a positive outcome in the plenary vote and to the start of the trilogue discussion as soon as the House is ready.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Rapporteur PECH. – Mr President, Commissioner, fish is one of the healthiest foods we consume, and the European Union is the world's largest consumer of these products. Almost 70% of the fishery products we consume are imported from third countries. For this reason, as rapporteur for the Committee on Fisheries, I have proposed to include in the EFSA Management Board a representative of the aquaculture sector. I note that, although the board has been increased, and in the proposal a representative of the food sector has been accommodated as a proposal, but without reference to the aquaculture sector and biotechnology to the south, in contrast to agriculture. I want to positively highlight the focus that is given to scientific arbitration. It is reinforced to ensure that evaluations are carried out on the basis of the best and most recent scientific information and that the risk assessment and the preservation/preparation of the analysis of these studies is independent, objective and, to this end, duly compensated. It is also positive that, in risk assessment, potential impacts on animal health and the environment are taken into account. Human health is not only the management of direct risks, but also the environment in which it is included.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Sommer on this report and, of course, by supporting all her proposals. I understand the objective of the proposal to strengthen transparency in the risk assessment process, but I would like to stress as a contact person with the Agency that EFSA is independent and scientifically irreproachable and sticks to the regulation in force.  However, I sincerely believe that there has been a lack of political ambition to make an in-depth reform of the Regulation and to update the tasks of EFSA which, after almost twenty years, is overloaded with tasks that depart from what is strictly food security. As regards EFSA transparency, it should be approved to other Union agencies such as ema and ECHA, i.e. information on basic applications and studies should be published at the time their scientific opinion is made public.  I agree that we must strengthen the transparency of the Agency, but without ideological tints and without conditions the innovation capacity of applicants.  Finally, this regulation in force established the early warning system, but despite being revised in 2011, we continue to have no harmonised procedure for action by all Member States and without strengthening the Commission's powers in the management of alerts. A simple support manual, as there is today, is not enough, and this is an opportunity to fix it and that social alarms like the ones we have had in the past are not repeated.

name: Pavel POC
text: on the part of the S&D Group. People want us to do more for food safety, and they also want to know how and on what basis the European institutions decide on their safety. In today's world, where money is unfortunately the driving force behind everything, the only chance is to have a robust authorization system that is resistant to influencing decision-making processes from outside, in which any possible fraud and manipulation will be easily detected and rectified. Our current authorization system is based on the applicant's obligation to prove the safety of their product. In the past, however, this may have led to some firms being able to buy favorable studies or, conversely, to conceal adverse results. We can now prevent these practices by providing independent scientists and the public with timely access to complete information.  Of course, there is nothing wrong with the fact that the industry is worried about its competitiveness. The protection of copyright and patents is important and is protected sufficiently by this and other legislation, there is no need to pay for it by reducing the quality of food safety.  There is no reason to delay the publication of a non-confidential version of the application which even the applicant himself does not expect to be harmed in any way by the publication. It is also out of the question that the European Food Safety Agency should be obliged, with public money, to prove the safety of substances for private profit. This will not be supported by our faction, and we have asked for roll-call votes to see who, on the contrary, wants to support it. Tomorrow's vote will make it very clear who is on the side of food safety and the legitimate demands of the European public, and, on the other hand, for whom food safety is just a boring obstacle to making the most of it.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank the Commission and the rapporteur, Renate Sommer. We have a very courageous and very intelligent report here. How do we make authorisation procedures more transparent? How can we prevent the procedures we have in the EU from losing confidence? The key is transparency – a lot of information that consumer associations and the public can and should be critical of. But what is also important is that we are talking about the entire food chain in the EU. We are not just talking about big corporations like Monsanto and its notorious glyphosate. We are talking about thousands of medium-sized companies operating in this sector. With such far-reaching legislation, we must also be careful not to kill off all innovation in Europe. What happens if a medium-sized company has a new recipe for concentrated feed, but it is too complicated to allow it in Europe? What happens then? Nothing happens.  The big corporations are moving their developments to China, and the medium-sized company is simply going bust. It is a balancing act between greater transparency, more safety on our plates, but also a procedure that is as unbureaucratic as possible, which is not only to be managed by the very big ones. This report and the rapporteur's proposals ensure that this is the first.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is a very important piece of legislation that we are discussing today. It is a little crowning achievement of much that the European Union has actually come to achieve. The consequence if we go too far is that we only release trade secrets. It doesn't increase confidence. Nor does it increase food safety, it simply drives industry out of Europe and we cannot have it.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the food industry in Europe is bumping from scandal to scandal. Just think of the horsemeat scandal or think of the fipronil scandal in our eggs.  One of the biggest scandals of this century is the re-approval of the highly harmful agricultural poison glyphosate. The Monsanto Papers showed in detail how long the arm of the industry is. Monsanto paid big money to scientists to demonstrate the so-called safety of glyphosate. The European authorities took that for a while those bodies are responsible for monitoring the safety of our food. Concerned citizens no longer picked it up and collected more than one million signatures for the citizens' initiative "Ban glyphosate!". According to the Party for Animals, the only responsible guide is the precautionary principle. Human and animal health and the right to a healthy living environment must always take precedence over the commercial interests of poison producers. Unfortunately, we have to note that the rapporteur does take sides with these producers. Fortunately, the Committee on the Environment and the Special Committee on Pesticides are taking a different line. Like us, they want to prevent industry in Europe from taking decisions. Citizens and independent scientists need to have early access to all the information and, of course, they also need to know who that information comes from.  Tomorrow, Parliament will have the opportunity to show once again that it is not giving in to the power of money, that it is not giving in to the power of industry. I call on you to choose transparency, reliability and independence. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last fifteen years, the European food sector has been through a number of crises. I would remind you that at the beginning of the 2000s we moved from the fear generated by bovine spongiform encephalopathy, more commonly known as 'mad cow disease', to that of foot-and-mouth disease or even that of dioxin chicken. We recently learned about how large global companies have long used pesticides or fertilizers that are potentially harmful to consumer health.  European citizens are increasingly becoming aware that every aspect of the agri-food chain must be controlled and made transparent, with the possibility of constantly accessing information concerning the product. That is why I welcome the proactive spirit shown by the Commission and the European Parliament on amending the regulations on transparency and sustainability of the food chain risk assessment process. The proposal follows on from the European Citizens' Initiative and in particular from the concerns expressed by the initiatives on the transparency of scientific studies used to evaluate pesticides. The opportunity to obtain information on the preliminary stages of the process and the advantage of being able to contribute to the study of risks will bring a certain benefit to the entire European food sector. I am glad that on this occasion we have made good use of the virtuous examples offered by Italy in terms of control and transparency. My hope is that this will not remain an isolated case. Also in the wake of what has been done in Italy, thanks also to the contribution of the sector associations, I hope that the implementation of the regulations will make it possible to achieve real transparency in favour of consumer choices, including with regard to the origin and traceability of food products, indicating the ingredients used in all foods without compromising downwards, so that deception is in fact prevented and conscious purchasing choices for European consumers are favoured.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, when I look at the story that lies ahead, I think we need to think about public confidence, but also business confidence. I would therefore like to thank our Renate Sommer as rapporteur on this subject.  As an example, I am thinking of the panicky incorrect risk communication by the Dutch authorities during the fipronil crisis in the summer of 2017 that caused a market disorder and major damage. This demonstrated the need for European coordinated risk communication and the fight against fake news and hate speech, while thanks to EFSA our food is still safer than ever before.  Family farms in the laying poultry sector are still struggling with the consequences and we need to find a solution to this.  Trust also requires transparency. The Commission's proposals do not offer a solution, but unfortunately cause new, enormous problems. With Mrs Sommer, I condemn the complete lack of an impact assessment, especially as the rules in this proposal will cause considerable damage to the innovation and competitiveness of European industry.  It is incomprehensible that the Commission has not had a follow-up assessment carried out. The authorisation of the European food, feed packaging, feed industry, plant protection products, plant breeding and flavouring industry in Europe is at stake. We must also think about this. I am opposed to disclosing details of production processes and related research studies in advance and from the time the application was submitted. This poses a risk to industry because of corporate espionage from third countries. Transparency can also be given after completion at the time of EFSA's scientific draft advice. I think we should fight each other for that.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, it is better to be late than not at all. A heartfelt thank you for the proposal you have presented, which you have also made very clear today. I believe that this is a whole series of improvements that Europeans have been waiting for for a long time. The European citizens' initiative, which has already been mentioned today, with more than one million signatures from 22 Member States, has clearly shown that the people of Europe not only want transparency in the authorisation of those substances that enter the food chain, but really insist on their right to do so. The proposal before us does both: it manages to create transparency here, and it naturally takes account of the legitimate interests of those who are here applicants. You yourself have said today, and we have discussed it at length: intellectual property rights, innovation and personal data are not jeopardised by this draft. It is simply a question of pointing out the published studies in connection with security risks wherever security risks are concerned, and wherever companies – and there is this clearly limited positive list – can demonstrate that they are causing economic damage from transparency, this does not happen. I believe that we have a very, very good, balanced report. I believe that what we voted on in ENVI meets precisely the expectations of Europeans. We really need to enforce this transparent risk assessment. I am also looking forward to the main points of tomorrow's vote being by roll-call procedure. This is because we really need to show who is worth the risk of the citizens, who is betting on health and who is only relying purely on industrial profits.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, ensuring the safety of our food chain is an essential task for the government. The whole debate on glyphosate has made one thing clear: the importance of greater transparency, the importance of independent investigations. We have emphasised this from the beginning.  We stand for evidence-based policies based on objective science. The risk assessments of the European Food Safety Authority, EFSA, are crucial in this respect. I would like to stress here that we must give EFSA absolutely the necessary tools so that it can play the powerful role that we expect from this authority. This proposal provides answers to these challenges and deserves our support. But at the same time, I recognise that the concern about, among other things, the timing of publication, that these concerns are legitimate, that there must be an answer to that. If we do not want to slow down innovation in the food sector, we must find the right balance and make workable choices.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: – Mr President, consciously or unconsciously, we use potentially dangerous substances in everyday life, for example in our car or in our smartphones. We even drink carcinogens, such as caffeine and alcohol. In agriculture, common farmers and organic farmers use resources to protect their crops. That makes sense because if a harvest fails, they have no income and we have no food.  It is extremely important that we have a scientific risk assessment to determine whether these drugs are dangerous to the environment, human or animal. Because let's face it: which one of you in the room knows the chemical formula of glyphosate? No one, so we leave it to science. What you see very often is that an outcome of a scientific assessment doesn't quite fit into our political street and we scream murder and fire. I always compare it a little bit to the situation where we sit on the bench at home and watch a football match where the referee sees a foul in a tackle on our favourite player. We wish that referee everything. But it is important that that referee is there, because without a referee no football match. That is why it is so important that we have a trustworthy risk assessment, that we do everything we can to strengthen the authority and that we do everything we can to strengthen transparency. Because if we don't have a referee to do the assessment for certain substances, we get bogged down again in a politics of welles and staples and we beat all innovation to death.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: – Mr President, I am of the opinion that, unfortunately, the Commission's proposal to publish confidential industrial studies when assessing the impact of the European Food Safety Agency is completely inadequate. The Commission is trying to reassure the public following the recent glyphosate scandal. However, it proposes only cosmetic changes, which will not in fact bring about any increase in transparency or a strengthening of the public interest in health protection. According to the European Commission, it will still be possible to refuse to publish scientific data and, for example, studies in relation to authorisation for GMOs, by pointing out the need to protect intellectual property rights or commercial interests. Moreover, the European Commission does not even envisaged the possibility of re-using the data without authorisation. This will not increase the number of toxicity studies. I miss the European Commission's commitment to ensuring sufficient funding for the European Food Safety Agency, without which the whole risk-setting process is a complete utopia. Unfortunately, we have not been able to address these shortcomings in the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, the unwillingness of EU citizens to have glyphosate residue in their food, when the World Health Organisation (WHO) has deemed it probably carcinogenic, is entirely understandable, and the more than one million signatures on the European Citizens’ Initiative indicate the intensity of concern. I have received more than 500 emails from the people of South-West England calling for greater transparency. In a process that was confusing and opaque, Member States chose to reauthorise glyphosate in the face of scientific evidence and widespread public concern. As called for in this report, we need much greater transparency about the process of risk assessment for the food chain, in order to restore public trust. Meaningful reform would be undermined if MEPs vote tomorrow to allow industrial secrecy to trump transparency. If the industry really has nothing to hide, then why preserve so-called industry secrets? People lose faith in their institutions when they can see that information is being concealed, or that they are being deceived. At a time when a cocktail of substances is entering our ecosystems and our bodies, we need to know how the EU decides whether this causes us harm. Let’s shine a light on the dirty work of the agri-businesses that prop up an intensive and unsustainable food system, whilst at the same time finding alternative agro-ecological solutions to replace the dangerous chemicals that are so widespread in our farming system.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, allow me first of all to thank Mrs Sommer for her excellent work. I am convinced of the need to take action to ensure greater transparency throughout EFSA's evaluation process and, above all, to improve public confidence in the credibility of scientific studies, which has been disputed several times and, specifically, in the case of the authorisation of gifosato. I would like to stress the importance of risk management in the use of substances and the need, therefore, for high scientific quality, as well as controls and audits in relation to the studies used. EFSA plays a very delicate role with great professionalism and competence but, in some cases, methodologies have been used that need to be improved, as I have pointed out several times. I refer to the case of anthraquinones where, in order to demonstrate their relative danger, analyses and studies have been carried out on similar substances and not on substances that are intended to be banned. We have also changed the structure of the Management Board, with two representatives of Parliament instead of one, and by extending the list of representatives of industry and civil society to include experts in public health, the agrochemical industry and the food industry. Finally, it is important to highlight the critical point of the proposal, which refers to the temporal news and the publication of the basic information and studies of the questions addressed to EFSA. On this point, I fully agree with what the rapporteur has said, so as not to sell off our industry.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: "Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for the work they are presenting to us today in plenary. European citizens expressed concern about transparency in EFSA's assessments – and it did so through a European citizen initiative – following reports used for the glyphosate assessment. I would like to begin by recognising that I was pleased with the reaction of the European Commission, which made a proposal to amend the legislation to ensure that demanded greater transparency. I believe that the proposal that came out of the Committee on the Environment responds precisely to these needs of consumers with a firm commitment to the protection of human health and the environment.  Risk management, assessment and communication have to respond to the precautionary principle and should be done through a clearly transparent, objective and independent process. That is why today I would like to ask that the house tomorrow approve precisely this proposal which came out of the ENVI Commission and that this ambition should continue, that there should not be a setback.  I would like to say that the amendments which allude to the need to go backwards and that the publications of the studies to be taken into account are finally carried out with the opinion, are a setback. To ensure public participation they must be available at first. And confidentiality should be reserved only for strictly commercial matters. We must give a clear message to the public and regain their trust. The ultimate goal is human health and the environment, and that's what I appeal to.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, when it comes to making legislation in this area, we should be guided by the principle of ‘follow the science’. Independent science—led, evidence-based policymaking is, in my opinion, essential. Equally, citizens of the European Union are right to expect reasonable levels of transparency from our institutions. For the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), as for other agencies, increasing transparency will encourage and increase public trust in scientific decision—making and the safety of the food we eat. However, we must, of course, ensure that commercially sensitive material is adequately protected. If essential parts of confidential business information are not safeguarded, it would hamper innovation and have a particular impact on small and medium-sized enterprises. I also have sympathy for concerns about an increased national level of involvement in the EFSA risk assessment process, on the grounds that it could be subject to increased political involvement, particularly with regard to changes in how EFSA recruits its Management Board.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Dear Commissioner, dear rapporteur and honourable colleagues. The decline in trust in institutions did not begin yesterday, let us remember, for example, the mad cow disease epidemic. The Regulation on general food law 15 years ago was an appropriate response to the challenge at the time, but it could not prevent all the scandals that followed. Over the years, however, consumers have become more aware and demanding. It wasn't until glyphosate happened that we saw that time was gone. We can agree that we still have room for manoeuvre to restore citizens' trust in institutions, but we are running out of time. We have an election at the door, we've got a bill to do.  With this report, we have the opportunity to show citizens that we are serious. If we do not serve them with the scientific rules on safe food today, tomorrow we will have a higher bill, which we will all pay, not just those who insist on the old rules of the game. Parliament is the right place to find compromises, but we must not allow ourselves to compromise at the expense of health. Citizens expect more swift and more transparent action by EFSA, they want to know what information and procedures have been established to ensure that food in trade is safe. More transparency will not harm anyone, and EFSA will become more credible. I understand some of the concerns of my colleague Sommerova, but I am convinced that we can do anything so that the competitiveness of our industry is not affected.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to welcome the commission's proposal, and I would like to commend you, Commissioner, for paying particular attention to the citizens' initiative 'Stop glyphosate' and to have heard the demands that were made by this citizens' initiative. Thank you also for paying attention to the pressure we have exerted here in Parliament on the issue, following the revelation of the Monsanto papers. Thank you for this proposal. I would also like to strongly denounce the European right which, in the vote in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Security, showed, Mr President, its true face by prioritizing the protection of intellectual property rights over the precautionary principle and the health of the 500 million Europeans.  I invite Mrs Sommer to read last week's vote in the Pesticides Committee, where we are calling - and we voted by a large majority - that the European Commission and the agencies be demanding on the most transparency, on the most independence and strict application of the precautionary principle, in order to protect the health of the 500 million Europeans.  We must be vigilant that national agencies - and this is the case with the BfR - no longer copy and paste industry studies, in order to regain the confidence of European citizens. We must be able to ensure that the studies used by the European Food Safety Agency are 100% reliable and free of any conflict of interest. It is about regaining the confidence of European citizens in our institutions, Mr President.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, first, let me make it clear that I welcome the principle behind this proposal. It is important to ensure access to studies and, indeed, to allow the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to have better access to relevant scientific evidence. This is all in the interest of transparency and public safety, which is paramount in everything we do as legislators. However, I have some concerns with the report that has been tabled for plenary this week, and I think we need to be careful about this vote and ensure that we find a more sensible, pragmatic and balanced approach to tackling this important issue. It is important that we give more careful consideration to what this proposed regulation is requiring of companies in terms of when the publication of information and underlying studies in relation to applications is due. In the text tabled by the committee, and indeed in the Commission proposal, food companies would need to inform EFSA immediately of the subject matter of studies commissioned. I feel we need to be careful here, and consider further the impact this immediate notification could have on innovation in the food sector. I share the fears which the rapporteur had during the committee negotiations that there could be a danger of ideas piracy, and that this could result in a perceived lack of protection for EU companies’ intellectual property. Maintaining the competitiveness of our EU food industry is extremely important for workers, farmers and citizens alike, and so we should ensure balance in imposing such an obligation. I welcome the suggestions by my colleague Ms Sommer for making the proposal more workable, including the requirement that EFSA should first draft a preliminary opinion, after which point the studies and non-confidential application material could be made public.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Thank you, thank you for the floor and also to all our European citizens, who are basically the reason why we are sitting here this evening discussing this regulation. Because if it had not been for the intensive struggle of the citizens to discuss this with glyphosate, we would not have had this regulation. I think it is a very good regulation, which is why I would like to thank the European Commission for listening to the citizens' initiative and listening to the European Parliament. That is a very good thing, and it is really gratifying, because this regulation actually gives us the opportunity to bring much more transparency, openness and sustainability into our entire food chain. And this is important when we have an internal market where our food is transported across many national borders. It is important that citizens are sure that they do not get sick of them. It is important that they know what meat they are eating, but it is also important that they know what pesticides are used in their food, and we will have a much better opportunity to do so with this regulation. Independent experts need to take a look at whether a pesticide is harmful or not, so that we should not just listen to what the chemical industry itself is saying. I think it's really important that we secure this. We are given some more opportunities to EFSA so that they can also make significantly better recommendations for us. At the very end, this means that we will have both cleaner and safer food, but that in reality we will also ensure that our European citizens can trust that we are really fighting for their interests. Thanks.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, the pursuit of greater transparency is crucial in modern political decision-making. This is also evident in the development of plant protection products and food products. People want to know what's on their plate and rightly so. They know on the basis of what considerations we take decisions that directly concern them in their daily lives. That is precisely why I think it is very good that the European Commission has come forward with a proposal on transparency in the European risk assessment in the food chain. I do not need to remind you of the many citizens' initiatives concerning, for example, the lack of plant protection products in order to illustrate this deep concern among citizens on this subject. Then we must listen to these concerns. I think that's self-evident.  As policy makers, we have more than one responsibility alone. Although full disclosure is desirable in some cases, there are also certain procedures in which total transparency can undoubtedly also involve risks. And this is one of them. Because, ladies and gentlemen, let's not fool each other. In the global industry there are always hijackers on the coast. Competitors are lurking and information is more power than ever. So if we want to support our own European companies and safeguard the jobs they provide, then imposing an obligation on them to immediately disclose all the secrets is the last thing I think we should do. What is more, they would achieve the opposite of what the citizens want, namely that companies no longer invest their returns in research and development for more secure products, with all the negative consequences that entails. If we really want Europe to become the world's greatest innovator, then we cannot do that to our companies in that area.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for its frankness on this proposal. This is the least the Commission can do after the glyphosate scandal accepts the further use of a pesticide that provides growing scientific evidence of the risk of cancer and other health damage, not only from the World Health Organisation, on the basis of non-public information. As far as food safety is concerned, it is essential that we end up with the kind of transparency that has been proposed in the process of scientific acceptance. At the same time, it is also necessary to take care of the innovation capacity and competitiveness of the European food industry globally. But not at the expense of human health.  It is very difficult for me to see the kind of innovation that would be threatened here. Especially since, when reading the Commission's proposal, these so-called backstles in terms of innovation and business secrets are more than sufficiently and very clearly written out. So I do not see that the Commission's proposal threatens the European food industry or agriculture in any way, let alone its innovation.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, first of all, I congratulate the rapporteur on her work. Public health and food safety are sensitive issues of interest to all European citizens. They are clearly always concerned about transparency of decision-making about food or other products placed on the market. That is why the food safety regulatory regime must be extremely serious in order to ensure its credibility and efficiency. Safety issues have a huge impact on both consumer confidence and market stability. In this context, I believe that there is a need to align EFSA rules in terms of transparency with those of other European agencies. At the same time, we need to ensure that studies carried out in laboratories in third countries meet the same quality standards as those in the European Union. However, the mechanisms created must not prejudice the economic interests of producers and allow ideas to be pirated. We believe that the preparation of a preliminary opinion from EFSA on the products tested would prevent this and provide the way for real public debate.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, citizens are increasingly interested in their food and are looking at how the European system works. The debate around glyphosate is the perfect illustration of this. It is our duty to respond to them and to ensure that our procedures are clear, in order to be understood, because what is not understood is feared. I am therefore in favour of strengthening the procedure and increasing transparency of the procedure, as a member of the European right, do not displease my colleague Eric Andrieu. I would also like to reiterate my commitment that decisions are always taken on a solid scientific basis, the only ones capable of allowing us to have indisputable positions so as not to fuel the food fears that some people are stirring. For this reason, the independence and proper functioning of our agencies, including the European Food Safety Authority (EEAS) are fundamental. We must give them the means to our ambitions. With regard to the publication of studies, we must strike the right balance as to when to make them public, between a desire for transparency and the protection of research and innovation in the European Union. Let's not forget that our businesses and SMEs face global competition. It is therefore essential to enable them to stay ahead of the curve in terms of development and innovation. Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues for supporting, in the committee vote, my amendment reminding us that, when signing trade agreements, the Union must ensure that the food laws of third partner countries are at least as protective of food security as European legislation, in order to guarantee the safety of 500 million European consumers and not to create distortions of competition for European producers.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President, thanks to this report, which is a response to the citizens' initiative, and to those of us who also sat on pest committees on Thursday afternoons, we have convinced us how the EFSA is needed, how it needs to be strengthened, to provide sufficient resources to ensure that procedures are as transparent as possible, as clear and as public as possible, so that people get and restore confidence in the institutions , which takes care, on the one hand, to prevent scandals in the food chain and, on the other hand, to play a key role in the registration of pesticides.  In pesticides, it's similar to human health. We will probably always need medication to do this when the immune system fails and when the plant will not be able to resist all pests or diseases, even though some people think otherwise, we will still need a fraction of the pesticides for quite some time. And here we need to keep up with the professionalism, to believe the institutions and to expand innovation and food production in Europe.  I don't want to be addicted to food coming from other continents. This report is going in the right direction.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the food safety of products circulating in the European Union is a precious asset, a conquest of civilisation. We cannot afford another case such as glyphosate, which undermines the entire EU authorisation system: our production of excellence and the protection of the health of all European citizens are at risk. We need clear and strict rules to put an end to the secrecy of industry studies, which are used to support the safety of pesticides, GMOs, food-related materials and other food-related products. The scientific assessment of the potential impact of pesticides and other products must not be a private affair between EU scientists and producers. We must act clearly, guaranteeing citizens access to information, on request, the publication of all relevant information and precise limits on the reasons for the confidentiality of certain information. Studies should be published as soon as they are submitted, to allow for in-depth consultation during the evaluation process.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the food scandals have shocked European public opinion. They're on the agenda. We had the mad cow scandal, the egg scandal, which also touched Greece, the glyphosate scandal. That is why the citizens have been mobilised: one million signatures in order to put an end to this affair at European Union level, as there is not even a guarantee for food itself, and so there is a huge risk to consumers themselves, to their health.
