We don't have transparency in scientific studies. There is a conflict of interest between the scientists who undertake – supposedly – to build the studies and the companies. That is why health must be at the forefront; health and consumer protection. But of course, when you have a process where businesses simply seek profit, one realizes that we are getting to these adverse results. There must be measures to protect public health.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Today we are taking a big and important step. We are calling here from the European Parliament for an end to dirty secrets in the authorisation procedure for pesticides, GMOs, food additives and novel foods. Democracy and science have a lot in common. They cannot be properly implemented under secrecy. They demand transparency. The wrangling over the authorisation of the pesticide glyphosate in 2017 sheds an uncomfortable light on the lack of transparency in this process of approving pesticides in the EU.  The European citizens' initiative Stop glyphosate was signed by more than 1.4 million citizens and the demands are in line with what we Greens have always been pushing for, namely that studies on the basis of which glyphosate is carried out in such authorisations should be transparent and published in scientific journals. It shows that we can influence! Accusations of so-called industry-driven research and undue influence showed that a lack of transparency undermines the quality of assessment as well as the confidence of European citizens in our institutions, and we shall change that.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, food, which is the most important factor for human survival, must be protected from risks relating to their health status as well as threatening the lives of the people who eat them. Similar attention should be paid to feedingstuffs. European Union legislation dealing with food protection must be based on a scientific basis and extended throughout the food chain in order to protect citizens. Although the European Food Safety Authority supports its scientific assessments, citizens do not trust it. One reason that exacerbates this concern among citizens is the fact that food often comes from third countries that have not been examined for their health status. There must therefore be transparency in order to protect the lives of citizens.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what do we really want to do? At the request of citizens, because we are making public policies for citizens, behold, the Commission comes up with a proposal to strengthen EFSA authority, new rules for this agency, which, in fact, ensure the reduction of risk in the food chain. Of course we need to strike a balance here with the interest of industry, but we cannot put it before the lives of citizens and before the quality of the food we eat. That is why I believe that we will take a step forward, and I appreciate the proposal from the Commission. Of course, there needs to be more transparency and there are ways to protect ideas and innovations. The important thing is to have very clear, transparent rules, known and the same set of rules to apply throughout the internal market. Commissioner, you may also answer what we do with food that is distributed, marketed within the internal market, but it is brought from outside, from third countries, if they have the same regime and how can we keep an eye on this.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the controversy over how much, what food information will be accessible to millions of consumers on the basis that the competitiveness of businesses is not affected reveals the mockery of transparency in their control and authorisation. You are talking about food safety in a European Union with a history of food scandals, with risks to the health of millions of people. A war of business giants is raging in the food industry with powerful lobbies. Food, the most vital human need, submits to profit. Small farmers are uprooted for the benefit of large agricultural and industrial farms in the agri-food sector. Eating habits are guided commercially. The food on the shelf is expensive. Their quality falls – for many, not all – while expired are given to impoverished people against tax exemptions in food groups. Hungry people around the world and in developed Europe are growing, when science and technology combined with the work of millions of people – farmers, workers – can provide plenty of cheap quality food for everyone. The other organisation of the economy, without monopolies and profit, is necessary for the food and health of the people.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened with great interest to the views expressed during this discussion and I am grateful for all the valuable insights and for the commitment in the House to addressing the transparency and sustainability of the European Union risk assessment process in the food chain. I heard a lot of support for the proposal today, and I am reassured by the fact that Parliament believes transparency is crucial in terms of Europeans’ trust in our work to protect them. I thank the many Members who have raised the issues of transparency, science and so on, especially Mr Andrieu and the members of the Special Committee on the Union’s authorisation procedure for pesticides (PEST). This proposal is for a targeted revision of the General Food Law. It is a targeted revision, which means that we are focusing just on ways of addressing transparency issues, because they are the main problem. As you know, the General Food Law was introduced in 2002, and now, after the fitness check, we know that it is fit for purpose. The targeted revision is designed to provide an ambitious response to calls for more transparency in the risk assessment process in the food chain.  Therefore, once again, allow me to emphasise that public disclosure of studies supporting applications for authorisation at an early stage is important, in order to increase citizens’ confidence in the risk assessment system, and also to restore trust in science and to avoid bias in science. Two weeks ago we had debates with presidents of industry and we explained once again that our proposal is a balanced one. Industry needs to postpone disclosure, but that is not the right answer in this situation. I am convinced that, on the basis of the positions expressed here, a good compromise can be reached on this issue. Please be assured that the proposal, while strengthening transparency, includes enough safeguards for business to enable innovation in Europe to continue. I would further mention, once again, that duly justified confidential information will remain protected, and there is no interference with existing intellectual property rights or other rights. That is crystal clear. In any event, enhanced transparency will contribute to strengthening a climate of consumer trust, which is beneficial for stimulating innovation – and I would emphasise that. The Union’s product safety system is recognised worldwide. Please compare the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) system: the openness of the data is much broader than what we have in Europe today. And what about companies in the United States? They are not complaining about that. So, let’s see how we can improve transparency, while not putting innovation at risk. On Ms Schreijer—Pierick’s question about impact assessment, as explained in the roadmap and the explanatory memorandum to the proposal, no initial impact assessment was carried out. The measures proposed focus on transparency and the way that the Commission and EFSA will gather and manage the evidence needed to perform their tasks on the basis of unchanged criteria. Secondly, duly justified confidential information is protected in addition to any existing intellectual property rights and data exclusivity rights. Therefore, incentives for innovation remain largely unchanged. Thirdly, the proposed measures have a particular impact on EFSA, which is publicly financed.  As to questions related to the possibility of equipping EFSA with more financial instruments, as you know, we are proposing in our new Multiannual Financial Framework to provide an additional EUR 62.5 million every year so that EFSA can recruit 106 additional workers and address the issues related to capacity problems. The proposal also addresses the long—term sustainability of the risk assessment process, and that of EFSA, in particular. EFSA’s role is, and will remain, crucial – actually as much as that of the Member States – in achieving a high level of protection of public health for European citizens.  Honourable Members, I thank you once again for your active engagement on this issue and I look forward to working closely together towards a strengthened climate of consumer trust in the food chain, and to seeing how we can move forward, starting with our debates in the months to come, with the Council, Parliament and the Commission together.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not understand why the Commissioner speaks three times as long as he has speaking time each time. Will I get this speaking time now? I am annoyed by this. The Commissioner has been lobbying all month, and he does not have to do it here. And you help him by letting him talk and not even giving him a hint on the clock. (The President: That is the Commission's privilege) But it always seems to be the case. Commissioner, do you really think that it is a balanced proposal, what you have brought, that it will remain a high level of protection for innovation and that everything will be wonderful? How can you know that? There was only a shortened consultation period for manufacturers and then over Christmas – yes, where the offices are empty. You have not provided an impact assessment, which you are obliged to do in the interests of better regulation. That is why we are all so divided here. Yes, we all want transparency in principle. That is what it is all about. That is why the Council does not really know where to go, because the impact assessment is missing. You have done a bad job and, at the same time, I am incredibly annoyed by the way in all these months you are calling Parliament, driving wedges into the political groups, driving between groups and trying to get your proposal through. Let me be elected to Parliament if you want to become a legislator! You are not the legislator, you are the Commissioner. I would like to draw your attention to this. It is not right that you are lobbying in this way.  I would like to say a word to the left of this Parliament – S&D, the Greens and the GUE: I find it outrageous to accuse the PPE-DE and the other groups, which are in favour of a moderate proposal that protects innovation and, at the same time, brings the public to the public, which he might want, to stand up against consumer protection and only for industrial interests. This is an aberration, an outrage.  Industry – I mean the manufacturers, yes, not the big bad industry; But, in your eyes, industry is always evil - industry - the manufacturers - that is also part of our society. They provide jobs that we urgently need. Incidentally, the food sector is one of the largest in the European Union. It provides millions of jobs, and all these workers are also consumers. Perhaps one should also think of their interests when there is a risk that companies will move their research and perhaps ultimately their production abroad.  And no, it's not always about glyphosate. The glyphosate debate was the reason for this story. But it is not acceptable for the whole food sector to be punished for this glyphosate debate and to be overlaid with rules that threaten existence. We are all in favour of transparency, but we want to do well.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Thank you very much, you have exceeded your time. Thus, the debate has become heated, but unfortunately I have to close it. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 11 December 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The risk assessments of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), in the evaluation of potentially harmful substances, often raise a lot of questions and encounter resistance from public opinion. More transparency about the procedures followed and the results of the investigation is absolutely necessary. And more transparency need not conflict with respect for the intellectual property rights of producers. That is why we support rapporteur Sommer's proposals. They are ambitious yet balanced. We are in favour of this change in the law because, as has been said, there is an urgent need for a transparent research method, while respecting the intellectual property and R&D efforts of the companies submitting dossiers to EFSA.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In the wake of numerous scandals, a public debate on pesticides took place, a debate which a citizens' initiative has taken over. In light of the success of this initiative, the Commission felt that public confidence in risk assessments should be strengthened. It has resolved to present a legislative proposal on EFSA's activities. EFSA's desire to increase transparency can only be welcomed. Nevertheless, the Commission is considering all these changes even before the conclusions of the PEST committee, the European Parliament's special committee on the authorisation procedure for pesticides. This suggests that this special commission was created only for form, which is very regrettable.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Sergei Stanishev, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the full application of the provisions of the Schengen acquis in Bulgaria and Romania: abolition of controls at internal land, sea and air borders (2018/2092(INI)) (A8-0365/2018).

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Vračić and his colleagues in the European Parliament who are taking part in this debate in order to once again express our support for Bulgaria and Romania's membership of Schengen. Oddly enough, there is no Representative of the Council here, the institution to which this debate and the report are actually addressed, despite the promise made in July to the LIBE committee by ministers from the Austrian Government that this will be on the Council's agenda during this half-year. Obviously, the Council has nothing to answer for its position. In fact, the truth is that for seven years the European Council has been in breach of European rules, not deciding on the membership of Bulgaria and Romania in Schengen. And all sorts of reasons have been highlighted since 2011. Including, here in this chamber, the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Mr. Rutte, a few months ago said that "a deal is a deal" and must be done by everyone. Only you messed up the deal, the agreement. He tried to mix the Schengen criteria with the Mechanism for Cooperation and Verification in the Field of Justice, and this is unfair to Bulgaria and Romania. However, the purpose of this report is not simply to once again call for the membership of the two countries in Schengen, as the criteria, all criteria, are clearly met. This is the assessment of the experts of both the Member States and the European Commission. It is about the fact that in recent years, especially this year, a new idea or compromise, as they say, for a "new type" of partial membership of Schengen. It is proposed that Bulgaria and Romania be accepted only by air and sea, postponing indefinitely the membership of the Schengen countries and free travel at land borders, which is contrary to both all the basic rules of the European Union and common sense. This idea seeks support and quite conjuncturally finds it. However, I would like to point out several main reasons why it is a dangerous precedent that should not be allowed. First, it will postpone once again indefinitely the release, lifting of controls at land borders. Secondly, the phased entry guarantees more economic losses and lost profits, both for Bulgaria, for its citizens, for the companies that export, as well as for European companies and European countries that import goods to Bulgaria and will have to waste a lot of time, and will cost the final product. Third, it will set the double standard in Schengen. I would like to stress that the Schengen legislation is not designed to function with two categories of countries – countries that are full members and those with only one foot inside.  I would therefore like to call on Parliament to support this report and to give a very clear vision and position to the European Parliament. It's been seven years since all the criteria have been met. A clear and firm sign must now be given to the European Council to fulfil its obligation.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission supports the full accession to Schengen by Bulgaria and Romania. President Juncker recalled this position in his State of the Union speech in September 2017. He called for the Schengen area of free movement to be opened immediately to Bulgaria and Romania and to allow Croatia to become a full Schengen member once all the criteria are met. This will be an important step towards a better and more harmonised protection of the Schengen external borders.  Bulgaria and Romania joining Schengen in full will not only enlarge the area of free movement, but at the same time make the Schengen tools more performant and increase security. As we know, the final decision lies with the Council and unanimity is required. Neither the Commission nor Parliament has a formal role in this process.  The Commission has suggested concrete steps for Bulgaria and Romania to participate already in two important elements of the Schengen acquis. It proposed that both Member States have passive access to the Visa Information System, as well as full access to the Schengen Information System. Parliament and the Council approved both proposals. The Commission will reiterate to the Council that the Schengen evaluations of Bulgaria and Romania were finalised during 2010-2011. These evaluations concluded that Bulgaria and Romania had fulfilled the relevant criteria for full accession. It’s now for the Council to decide and it’s high time for this to happen.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what we are discussing here today is unfortunately not a new subject. Already in 2011 this Parliament approved the entry of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen Area, advocating the immediate abolition of internal border controls with these two countries. I had the honour of being Parliament's rapporteur on this issue 7 years ago and also this year, through the annual report on the state of Schengen, I advocated the full and immediate accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the Schengen area. Today, with this report by Mr Stanishev, which I take to congratulate him on his excellent work, I maintain the same position. It is important to remember that all the requirements are met and only because unanimity is required in the Council, or the political opinion of some Member States, Romanians and Bulgarians are still treated as second-rate European citizens.  At a time when several Member States have imposed illegal controls at internal borders, as this Parliament has already denounced, and when the assessments reveal worrying flaws in the protection of their borders, it is difficult to understand the reticence towards Bulgaria and Romania.  And for those who invoke the issue of corruption and the problems that still persist in these two countries, let us be clear: corruption is not a criterion for schengen membership, but if we want it to be, then it should be for all Member States, indistinctly. We can't have evaluation criteria that are just for some and not for everyone. It is true that the Romanian Government has alarmingly destroyed the advances made in recent years in the fight against corruption and this cannot fail to merit our firm condemnation, but I have no doubt that Bulgaria and Romania must now enter Schengen and should be able to benefit from the area of free movement as European citizens.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sergei Stanishev, for this report. I also thank Mr Coelho for the old report, which, in fact, says the same thing - Romania and Bulgaria should have been members of Schengen for a long time. Romanian citizens, Bulgarian citizens have been discriminated against for over 7 years. Today, we say here in plenary and tomorrow we will vote to stop this discrimination against these citizens of ours, of Romanians and Bulgarians. It is a simple political game of the Council, which has not even made the effort or had the good will to come forward today to listen to our grievances, but I am speaking to you Commissioner and I hope that you will pass on to the European Commission that it will under no circumstances accept additional conditions for the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to the Schengen Area. I ask you, Commissioner, to tell President Juncker and all Commissioners not to accept that Romania and Bulgaria should be received only with air and sea borders, but also with land borders. Why is that? Because we meet all the technical criteria, because we have invested a lot of money from tax payers in both Romania and the European Union and Bulgaria to secure European borders. And we are doing this very well, and Mr Coelho and his colleagues who have worked on the dossiers know very well how well we are working to secure the difficult borders of the European Union. Stop discrimination, dear colleagues in the Council of the European Union, and respect European law, as you ask others.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, let me first congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Stanishev, on this report. We are political opponents at home, but his report is pro-European. Everyone who thinks in this chamber and declares themselves pro-European should support it. The decision not to have Bulgaria and Romania in Schengen is purely political. All technical criteria are met, all requirements are made, but the suspension of Bulgaria and Romania is due to internal problems in countries such as the Netherlands, countries such as Germany, countries like Austria, and this is wrong, unfair, two-faced and hypocritical. Such decisions, dear, reinforce scepticism in Eastern Europe regarding the European Union, because this political decision has its economic dimensions, because perhaps the most European economic activity in Bulgaria and Romania is transport, forwarding. More than 150,000 families in Bulgaria are supported and live by transport. And today from Romania, from Bucharest to Ruse 70 km you travel 12–13 hours. And today from Blagoevgrad to Thessaloniki, where there are 200 km, you travel much more time. This hinders economic activity, destroys the efforts of these people and makes them poor, and causes them to emigrate. Thus, the political solution behind which gentlemen like Rutte are hiding, gentlemen like the people who rule Germany and Austria, creates emigration and empties our countries from young and enterprising people, and we cannot allow this to happen, dear. This report must be accepted and approved and this hypocrisy must be stopped.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, I am saddened to note that today is by no means the first time that the European Parliament has taken a clear and firm position that the criteria met for membership of the Schengen area must lead to the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to Schengen. Seven years later, the Council's inaction requires us to look again. I have repeatedly stressed and will reiterate today that effective border security for the whole European Union cannot be achieved in full without full access by Bulgaria and Romania to all information systems. Granting only partial access to both parties because they are not members of Schengen leads to vulnerability of our border systems. The issue of the costs to the European economy that internal borders generate has been repeatedly raised. Imports and exports to both countries have been severely affected by the waiting time at internal border crossing points. The impact on transport operations to and from some of the largest maritime ports in southern Europe is negative. I'm a convinced European. The majority of Bulgarian and Romanian citizens support the values and ideas of the Union. We are for the strict application of the Common European Law. Its violation for so many years opens up big questions about the European Union's capacity for self-regulation and its sustainability. That is why I thank you, all the colleagues in the European Parliament, who have not for a moment wavered about compliance and taken the right position. The double standard applicable to Bulgaria and Romania is discriminatory towards the citizens of both countries, and the blatant injustice leaves doubts about the rule of law, the power of European institutions and destroys trust. They have a bitter sense of secondary citizenship in the Union. It is long time before the Council proved that the rules are the same for all and urgently to take the necessary actions to bring Bulgaria and Romania into Schengen at all land, sea and air borders.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, Dear Mr Stanishev, under the 2005 Act of Accession to the European Union, the only condition for Bulgaria and Romania to enter Schengen is the successful fulfilment of the necessary criteria. The successful fulfilment of the criteria was confirmed by the Council on 9 June 2011, when the Council stated that Bulgaria and Romania had fulfilled the conditions in all areas. Seven years ago, the criteria were met by Bulgaria and Romania, but for seven years now the entry of the two countries into Schengen has not happened. Some Member States oppose, arguing that they are not in the criteria they have written in advance. Member States that are opposed to Bulgaria and Romania's entry into the Schengen area grossly violate the rules that they themselves have adopted and voted on. This is a drastic and extremely bad example of the application of double standards. Double standards for food, double standards for Schengen. This attitude towards Bulgaria and Romania is extremely unfair and offensive to both countries. This is an undemocratic and non-European attitude. The idea of a so-called two-step approach to removing checks first at air and sea borders, then on land borders, would be a legal paradox and would be a continuation of the dual standard policy. When we talk about the rule of law, it is nice not only to be beautiful words and phrases, but also real actions, which means that once a Member State has met the criteria for entering Schengen, checks at land, air and sea borders should be abolished immediately, because such are the rules and they must be respected.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, dear Sergei Stanishev, I arrived at this European Parliament in 2009 and, as Chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and former Minister of Justice of Spain, I took the reading of the Lisbon Treaty, which came into force precisely that year, and the area of freedom, security and justice , whose first promise — Article 67 — is the free movement of persons within integrated management of the Union's external borders. And since 2009, no less than nine years ago, this European Parliament has been calling for the full incorporation of Bulgaria and Romania into this area of free movement of people because they have done their homework ever since. We have consistently called for the Council's decision to adopt a single legal act recognizing the total abolition of land, sea and air borders with Bulgaria and Romania to be a reality, because, as long as it is not, the European Union will continue to fail to its promise. Where the European Union, the area of freedom, security and justice, contributes the most, the European Union still has an outstanding account with Bulgaria, Romania and with Bulgarians and Romanians.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, since I was elected a member of this Parliament, I am a member of romania and Bulgaria entering the Schengen Area, both myself and my Fellow Romanians, Bulgarians and other colleagues from other countries. The technical arguments were repeated hundreds of times, Parliament itself voted several recommendations to the Council, but the Council decided, each time, otherwise. The impression of our compatriots is that we are being housed in the antechamber, like poor relatives of the European Union. And yet, the great problems of the Union come neither from Bucharest nor from Sofia. According to Eurostat data, Romania and Bulgaria are the countries where citizens have the most confidence in the European Union. In order to be welcomed into the Schengen Area, should we no longer trust the European project? What we are seeing is that the Union has stopped at a point where the Member States are no longer sovereign, but they are also not equal to be able to really talk about solidarity. We need to give impetus to the European project, there is a need for reform and involvement, there is a need for the deep accession of citizens. The reception of Romania and Bulgaria in Schengen is a step in this direction.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, there are very few to argue against the claim that the Schengen area is one of the major achievements of European integration. As a powerful enabler of the free movement of persons, goods and services, it has brought significant benefits to European businesses and citizens. It especially allowed the latter to directly experience the four freedoms of the single market. It is not surprising, therefore, that they place it at the top of the most cherished EU accomplishments. All this makes the fact that 11 years after their accession, Romania and Bulgaria are still not members of the area difficult to understand and especially difficult to explain to the citizens of these countries. Seven years have passed since the evaluation process confirmed that the two countries fulfilled the necessary conditions for the application of the Schengen acquis in all areas, and Romania and Bulgaria are still not members of the borderless area. This is a fundamentally unequitable situation in the EU, not just because the two countries have invested massively to increase their law enforcement capacity to meet all technical compliance criteria, but also because the continued maintenance of border controls has a large negative impact on the economies of these two Member States. Just as importantly, the failure to apply the Treaty provisions undermines the credibility of and erodes support for the EU – as recent Eurobarometer surveys keep demonstrating. It is in the whole EU’s interest that the Council treat all Member States equally and grant fully-fledged Schengen membership to these countries.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want from the outset to thank all my colleagues, regardless of the political group, who today, here, once again, stress with the rapporteur that Romania and Bulgaria meet all the conditions to be in the Schengen area. Moreover, the Council itself, in 2011, agreed to the verification and evaluation carried out by the specialists and it was found that, not only did it and did the lesson as a colleague said, Romania and Bulgaria had spent, they made investments to meet the Schengen regulation. Unfortunately, the unruly student is not here, the council is not here. Commissioner, we are in a critical situation with Europe. What does the Council really want? Why are we still 750 MEPs here, if 27 states, not 27 states, but one, two, three heads of state decide to break a regulation that is very clear and which the two states fulfil. We are talking about the freedom of movement of citizens here, we are talking about the fact that there are economic losses, and we are talking about the fact that there is now clear discrimination between states and between citizens of states. I believe that I will make a letter, I have made many letters and I have often spoken about this issue, addressed to the Council, proposing the abolition of the European Parliament. If democracy is upside down and a Parliament, which has the highest representativeness, has so many times a resolution and a point of view on this subject, if a Commission has a point of view on this subject, if the evaluators and specialists say that we fulfil the conditions, why are political reasons invented? Because they're simply political reasons.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr Speaker, accession to the Schengen area and the consequent abolition of internal border checks must be a clear and transparent process. There are concrete criteria, so after their fulfilment there should be no delay for political reasons. We must bear in mind that free movement without checks is one of the main benefits of Union membership in the eyes of citizens, so any over-politicisation of this issue undermines their trust in the European institutions. This is especially the case when the Council and Parliament have a completely different approach to such an important issue. In my opinion, the Council's approach is wrong and introduces legal uncertainty. Since I come from Croatia, a country having a strategic goal of joining Schengen, I really hope that in our case it will not be politicized this much.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, first of all I congratulate the rapporteur on his work. Free movement is a fundamental privilege of the European Union. Since 2011, the Council has concluded that Romania and Bulgaria fulfil all technical conditions for access to the Schengen area. Today we are providers of peace, security and stability in the region, and this refusal to enter this space is likely to lead to an increase in populism and extremism in the region. There is talk in public debates of economic interests that determine the position of countries in the Council, such as the Netherlands. I would like to point out that he is one of the largest investors in Romania, and they have significant losses in this context. At the same time, do not forget that the port of Constanta was not and is not for sale. I know that in Romania we have problems with a disastrous government, but the Council must understand that access to the Schengen area is not granted to the few ministers of the PSD-ALDE government, but to the millions of Romanian citizens and businesses in Romania, who cannot be punished and must enjoy the same rights as all citizens of the European Union. Today, Romania has the largest military contribution to Frontex. In other words, we are good at defending the borders of the European Union, but we are not good at being in Schengen. The Council is obliged to respect Romanians and Bulgarians and must immediately receive the two states in this space.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. Chairman, I congratulate my colleague Stanishev on a report that deserves the full support of the European Parliament. It's time to start consistently applying the rules we set for ourselves. Bulgaria and Romania have met all preconditions for schengen entry and the abolition of border controls on land, sea and air. Two-speed Schengen needs to be abolished, and I welcome the repeated call on the Council to include in the Schengen area two members who met the conditions seven years ago through a single act.  I come from a country that is in the process of meeting these same criteria, a country that successfully controls Europe's longest external border, and that is why I expect the same treatment for Croatia. This position is also shared by the rapporteur, for which I especially thank him.  Schengen - one of the most visible achievements of European integration - must not be a collateral victim of the deficit of our security policies. It is unacceptable that in 2018 Bulgaria and Romania are still outside Schengen, and Croatia, the bloc's youngest member, fenced off from neighbouring members with barbed wire.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the implementation of Schengen is a farce, ladies and gentlemen! You see this when you come to Strasbourg. No one can go out to Strasbourg airport unless a passport check is passed. Do you think that's right? Even today coming from Athens we went through a passport check. We passed by a place that said arrival from international flights. The same is happening in Brussels. There is quarantine and illegal passport control of Greeks coming from Athens. That is the reality, because Schengen is now a farce. They apply Schengen only to those who want and adopt exceptions and do not apply it by specific countries depending on what suits them. This is a reality and this must be denounced as a whole! One comment for friends from Bulgaria: What is now being observed is that the path of illegal immigration from Turkey to Bulgaria has changed and then thousands of illegal immigrants are entering Greece illegally; and we have specific facts. This must be careful, because all this is shaping up to be a bad situation overall for both Bulgaria and Romania and Greece.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second time this year that we have voted on a resolution to accept Romania and Bulgaria in the Schengen area. The previous resolution had no effect. Why is that? Because the Council has not taken any decision on this, and behold, today, it is the Council that is missing from the Chamber, although this discussion in plenary, although this resolution, which we are going to vote on again, is mainly addressed to the Council! It is the Council that does not respect the rights of the two countries. I would also like to thank all colleagues who voted for the previous resolution, and I again ask my European colleagues to vote positivefor the acceptance of Romania and Bulgaria in the Schengen area. This time, I believe, it is necessary to set a deadline so that the citizens of the two countries enjoy as much as possible the same rights as all European citizens have. Romania and Bulgaria have fulfilled the technical conditions for many years, and moreover, they apply the rules of access to the Schengen area and cooperate excellently with the Member States on their compliance and on the detection of situations contrary to specific legislation. I urge the acceptance of the two countries into the Schengen area and propose that we set a specific deadline. Let's talk with the cards on our faces. Romania has not been accepted into the Schengen area until now because of the economic interest of some countries. But the European Union belongs to all Member States, not just some of them.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, Romania and Bulgaria have been ready for several years to be a full part of the Schengen system, but internal political issues in some Schengen countries have prevented this from happening so far. As far as Romania is concerned, there is also a concrete interest of an important country, the Netherlands, which defends its trade advantage. Yes, today, Romania has a big problem with an irresponsible government, which has the wrong rhetoric in relation to the European Union and an even more wrong approach in the area of justice, of the functioning of the rule of law, but also in the economy. But keeping Romania out of the Schengen area will give water to a nationalist-populist rhetoric or even the Euro-cynical rhetoric of the current government. It would be right and just for Romania and Bulgaria to be part of the Schengen system and this would be in the interest of the better functioning of the Schengen system, but also of better European construction. The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – It is very difficult to understand why, today, although we have to talk or want to talk about Romania and Bulgaria entering Schengen, we are talking about how badly the economy is going in Romania, when we have the greatest economic growth in the European Union and this for many years under the social democratic government. We're talking about some untruths and we're talking about the subject. Let us get used, fellow Romanian Members, to stop swearing, to stop defaming this country here in Brussels! Let us focus on what needs to happen here and what this report should mean, Romania and Bulgaria in Schengen! The question is why you do this.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I do not think that was a real question. You can answer such a question, but I would ask Members, please, not to use the blue card to make comments.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – No one defamed Romania, I did not do it in my intervention. I have made it clear and clear that there is a problem with Romania today, due to the current government, which has the wrong rhetoric towards the European Union, which is doing the wrong things, primarily in the judiciary, but also in the economy, despite economic growth. This increase is wasted on certain expenses that will not add value. But Romania and Bulgaria have the right to enter Schengen. Romania has the right to enter Schengen and will enter, despite the irresponsibility of the current government.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The Bureau keeps that you agree on the Schengen issue, even though you have different views on internal policy issues in Romania. I give the floor to the next speaker.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, in this most important democratic institution of the European Union, we are asking for justice for Romania and Bulgaria. We demand justice for Romanian citizens and Bulgarian citizens. We call for Romanian citizens and Bulgarian citizens to stop being discriminated against compared to other citizens of the European Union. Romania and Bulgaria, ladies and gentlemen, fulfil the conditions for accession to the Schengen area. They already behave and act as de facto members of the Schengen area and manage thousands of kilometres on the external borders of the European Union. How can we ensure the safety and security of European citizens when, on the external borders, Romania and Bulgaria are not members of Schengen? How can we ensure security when you see very well what is happening with terrorist attacks, illegal immigration into Europe? And it calls for an increase in the security of the European Union. How is it possible to ensure this without Romania and Bulgaria? Ladies and gentlemen, it is a shame that we do not have the Council present. Please, Mr President, come forward and ask why the Council was not present today.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, despite the fact that both Bulgaria and Romania qualify to become full members of the Schengen Treaty, the Council is blocking and not giving them this opportunity. Of course, this has direct implications both in economic and, above all, practical matters, because controls are carried out at the borders of the two countries. Moreover, because of the European Union's emphatic failure to control the flows of migrants, especially illegals, to Europe, they often carry out checks at their borders and in practice the Schengen Treaty has been abolished. However, this does not mean that the Council should deny Bulgaria and Romania the right to become members at the time when they qualify. On the other hand, let us bear in mind that the enlargement of the Schengen area is often used as a means of serving certain policies of the European Union, such as that of the creation of the security union and the reform of asylum. Nevertheless, I repeat that Romania and Bulgaria have the right to join Schengen and they must become.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to first thank Mr Stanishev for this report, congratulate him and his re-election as President of the Party of European Socialists, good luck to you. I also thank Mr. Qualieu for his report and his commitment to the subject. I think it is indicative that the European Council is missing from this debate today, at least from courtoisia they could have sent someone here. I think all experts are aware that there is no risk to the Schengen area from Bulgaria and Romania. On the contrary, the opposite is the fact that when Bulgaria and Romania become full members of the Schengen area, we will have more security in this area. Links cannot be made between the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism and the Schengen criteria. There can be no double standards, it discourages European citizens. Bulgaria wants to be part of all integration processes in the European Union, as well as Schengen and the euro area, as well as the Banking Union and the Defence Union, and especially before the European elections, the Council must finally give a clear signal that there are no double standards. We can't go on with this. Yes, I understand that there are elections, I understand that there is populism, but finally a final decision has to be made.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, colleagues, it is a rather embarrassing situation for European construction that the Council is missing this evening at a very important discussion about European construction, namely construction and what is in the Schengen area. But because we have the Commission and the Council present, we all know that they have repeatedly argued in recent years that both Romania and Bulgaria, since 2011, have met all the technical criteria relating to full integration into the Schengen area. We must also not forget that these two countries are part of the Visa Information System and the Schengen Information System, systems put in place precisely to better manage and defend the external borders of the European Union. But paradoxically, if not absurdly, the Council refuses the full integration of these two countries into the Schengen area. That is why I call on the Council, even in absentia, to take a positive decision in this regard. We can no longer tolerate such a situation and I will also say, as a Romanian, that the port of Constanta belongs to Romania and the Romanians and is not for sale.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, indeed, the Commission’s position on Bulgaria’s and Romania’s accession to the Schengen area is clear and unequivocal: Romania and Bulgaria met the criteria of Schengen membership. So our position is that the Council hold open the Schengen area of free movement to Bulgaria and Romania immediately. However, the final decision lies with the Council; we know that unanimity is required, and the Commission doesn’t have a formal role in this process.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues who spoke out in favour of supporting the report. I would especially like to thank Mr Coelho, who was the shadow rapporteur, and the other shadow rapporteurs. He was dealing with this matter seven years ago, preparing the Parliament’s report. What we are facing is a shame. The Council is absent because they have nothing to say. What can they say? We  are violating European legislation and the rules. That’s what they should say. In reality, the situation is the following: we are discussing today the destiny and life of 30 million European citizens. Each time a Bulgarian or Romanian citizen comes to the Schengen border, they feel personally that they are being treated like second—class citizens of the European Union. That’s it. It’s very modern today to express concerns about the lack of trust in the European Union. It comes from a very simple thing. Words have been devalued by actions or inaction. When there is a huge gap between what we say and what the Council should do, and what is being done or not done, this is a major source of disappointment for the citizens. This is why I think the best thing that the Parliament can do tomorrow is to send a very powerful message, with a big majority, to the Council: do your duty and fulfil your obligations. The countries have done their homework. You should accept Bulgaria and Romania at all Schengen borders. Otherwise, they will be irrelevant. If the leaders who achieved so many things for the European Union in the past had acted as some of the leaders in the Council are doing today – thinking about public opinion polls today and about what happens the next day, but not in the longer term – we would never have the European Union as it is today. That’s the reality.  (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – More than 10 years after Bulgaria's accession to the European Union and seven years after the successful passage of the technical assessment for accession to Schengen, Bulgaria is not yet part of the free movement area. It is unacceptable that this violation of European rules and norms does not imply the imposition of additional, especially politically motivated, criteria that have no basis in European legislation!  Linking our adoption in Schengen to a mechanism that is not generally applicable to all Member States but is solely conceived for two specific countries is evidence of the application of double standards within the European Union. More worryingly, this is an attempt to create a two-speed Europe – not on the basis of a member state's sovereign decision to accede or not to a European solution, but on the basis of a policy imposed from the outside.  It is time for the leaders of certain Member States to realise that the European Union is one for all and that the rules apply to all of us in the same way. It's time to stop breaking the laws when it's more convenient for them, and then rebuke others for not following European norms! It is time for Bulgaria and Romania to become part of Schengen!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS

name: Anne SANDER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to welcome the role played by the decentralised agencies of the European Union. Spread throughout Europe, they are an expression of the polycentrism of the European project and the european Union's desire to be close to its citizens by truly anchoring itself in the territories. These agencies, which are often unknown to the general public, are nevertheless essential to the proper functioning of the European institutions. They are the right-hand man, providing them with technical expertise on a wide range of subjects. And in the social sphere too, agencies are involved, often behind the scenes, in the construction and implementation of European policies. Tonight we are talking specifically about three linchpins committed to building a social Europe, following the momentum initiated by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, and very widely relayed and materialised by the commitment of Commissioner Thyssen, which I would like to welcome. These three agencies are the Eurofound agency, working on living and working conditions, the EU-OSHA agency, which focuses on the health and safety of workers, and the agency Cedefop for the development of vocational training.  In order for these three agencies to keep pace with the reforms initiated, it was essential to be able to provide them with a framework and tools adapted to new challenges. I welcome this in the sense that we have been able to achieve this with my colleagues in charge of OSHA and Eurofound, whom I would really like to welcome and thank, both my fellow rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs, because we have really worked together, with the Council and the Austrian Presidency as well, to reform the founding regulations of these agencies. As rapporteur for the regulation on the European Centre for Vocational Training, Cedefop, my priority was to lay a sound and solid foundation for the effective functioning of the agency, without affecting its DNA, namely its tripartite governance structure placing employees, employers and states on an equal footing. In this reform, we have achieved a more transparent and closer functioning of the citizen. The proposed new rules reinforce the role given to the European Parliament. In concrete terms, our institution, the voice of more than 500 million European citizens, will now be represented by an expert on the agency's board of directors. MEPs will also meet the candidate for director. In order for the Cedefop to move to a higher gear and work better, we have also strengthened the role of the director. Finally, the new regulations set requirements to better respect the gender balance within the agency. What impact will these new rules have on citizens? The Cedefop will be able to function better and thus work better on vocational training. The challenge for our citizens is more skills, because that is what we have to aim for, of course. Unemployment, and in particular that of young people, is still extremely high and the challenge for the European Union in the coming years will be to ensure that our citizens have the skills to face the new digital challenges or the energy transition.

name: Czesław HOC
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Today's economy is already – or should be – a knowledge-based economy in which human capital is the most valuable and valuable resource of any business. After all, it is human capital that determines the survival and development of every business. Therefore, the future and current employee should be trained and educated. Then offer him an attractive job offer, in which he will work in safe, health-promoting and productive conditions. Moreover, the worker must be convinced that at all times the relevant institutions ensure the quality of work and the continuous improvement of his living and working conditions. And it is important that this process is rewarding and generate tangible benefits for the worker, the employer and the governments of the Countries of the European Union. Hence today's debate on improving and adapting to the new economic, social and even political realities and conditions of the three European institutions, namely the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA), the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) and the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions (Eurofound).  At this point, I would like to sincerely thank my fellow rapporteurs on the package of regulations on EU-OSHA, Cedefop and Eurofound: Annie Sander and Enrique Calvet Chambon. It was a very good and very friendly cooperation lasting almost two years. We have held eight triathly, a very large number of shadow rapporteurs and technical meetings with advisers from the Council and the Commission, as well as with the services. I would like to express my separate thanks to the Representatives of the Council and the European Commission for constructive and substantive discussions and common-sense compromises.  In order to better organise the discussions, the Council Presidencies decided to address the proposals for three tripartite agencies in the package, which was the main focus of the Social Questions Working Group.  Interinstitutional negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission began in spring 2018. An agreement on Cedefopu and EU-OSHA was reached at the seventh trilogue meeting on 16 October. On Eurofound, an agreement was reached on 9 November.  The revision of the three regulations has created an opportunity to provide anti-fraud measures, a conflict of interest policy and the conclusion of a headquarters agreement. Ex-post and ex-ante evaluations, which are the main principles of proper budgetary control, have also been introduced into the Regulations. The revision also harmonises the programming and reporting provisions with the requirements set out in the revised Financial Framework Regulation. The terminology on governance structure is currently in line with the 2012 Joint Project on Decentralised Agencies. As regards EU-OSHA, the provisions of the new Regulation, compared to the Regulation establishing the Agency in 1994, clearly define the role of the Agencies in providing the Union institutions and bodies and the Member States and social partners with objective technical, scientific and economic information as well as the expertise they need to formulate and implement policies to protect the health and safety of workers. As proposed by Parliament, the key point of the EU-OSHA negotiating agreement was the presence of a Representative of the European Parliament on the EU-OSHA Management Board. The role of executive director has also been clarified. In addition, the candidate will have to appear before the relevant parliamentary committee, i.e. the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL).  The European Parliament's team, working together in accordance, has achieved success in the trilogue negotiations by introducing the amendments we have proposed.
