name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Yana Toom's report, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on education in the digital age: challenges, opportunities and lessons to be learned in defining EU policies (2018/2090 (INI)) (A8-0400/2018).

name: Yana TOOM
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all I have to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, who worked in a really good cooperative spirit. According to an Oxford study prepared for the Commission, in the next 25 years, 30% –almost one third – of today’s jobs in Europe will disappear. They simply will not exist anymore. Janitors, taxi drivers, postmen and low—skilled workers will be replaced by cleaning-machine operators or robot station managers. This will happen pretty soon, during the lifetime of MEPs, even taking into account that our average age is 55. When we retire we can allow ourselves to observe changes from the sidelines, but our children and grandchildren will find themselves at the epicentre of this evolution. Their level of digital skills will determine not only the welfare of our descendants but also the future of our common project, a united Europe. While working on this report, representatives of all the political groups agreed that having or not having digital skills will become the basis of a new social divide in the near future. On the other hand, a high level of digital education will open new opportunities for economic growth. It’s a challenge for which – let’s face it – our education system is not ready. At a time when there is nothing to do on the labour market without a knowledge of programming languages, we are discussing how many more schools in remote areas will receive an internet connection this year. Everyone knows that, after graduation, each student must have a certain level of knowledge in mathematics, languages or biology, but we do not have a universal mandatory system for evaluating digital skills. Moreover, in Europe there is no set of professional requirements for an information technology teacher – and the extent to which teachers use technology in class differs across EU Member States like day from night. This report therefore calls on the Commission, at least in its next term of office, to develop an EU—wide strategy for education in digital skills. Our current approach consists of loose projects from various departments, which are all on a voluntary basis. It is important to set common goals for all Member States to reach a certain level of digital skills. If no goals are set, there is little motivation to invest. It is important that digital skills are assessed so that a proper comparison can be made. Therefore, the report calls for the creation of an assessment based, for example, on a Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) model. Of course, teachers have to be at the core of this development and they need to be properly trained and assisted. As teachers are already under increasing work pressure, this should not entail extra workload. Finally, the approach should be based on lifelong learning. Technological development will not stop, and we will have to adapt throughout our lives to new changes. We need to be able to recognise them and to learn how to learn. Those unable to adapt will be left behind. This is not only about the labour market: technology has become a part of our daily lives. Banking, doing taxes and even health care are becoming more digital. In addition, our social and political lives now develop online. Devices have entirely changed not only the way we communicate but also the way we consume information and form our opinions. This all requires skills: media literacy, etiquette online, cyber hygiene and protection of personal information. Those who do not know how to use online communications in a proper way will either be easily manipulated or simply left out of political participation. It is crucial to ensure that everyone profits from technological development, and education is the best way to start.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Indeed, the world is undergoing a huge transformation and education systems need to adapt to digitalisation and the rapid and continuous development of technologies. This certainly requires resources, and the transformation of education systems, the continuous training of teachers and the technical equipment of schools can only be imagined with considerable financial effort. Member States should therefore provide adequate budgetary resources for education. Unfortunately, there are countries where these amounts are still less than 4% of GDP. While in the Nordic countries this indicator is 7-8 percent, the last in Romania in this respect is only 3.1. Romania's backlog is also worrying because bulgaria and Greece, which are next in line, are already paying a full percentage point more for education, at 4.1 percent. These figures show that underfunding of education systems could cause the break-up of these countries to increase over the period ahead.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commissioner. I have to say that I fully agree with the indications that come from this report. There is an urgent need for Europe to adopt a shared educational strategy to prepare students – but also adults, in the logic of lifelong learning – for the new digital environment. The acceleration of the transformations that digital causes in professions but also in daily life, in the increasing modification of all jobs, makes it absolutely essential to adapt education systems not only, I agree, for the use of digital technologies, but also in terms of teaching methodology, educational research, digital skills and teacher training. It can be an extraordinary opportunity to rethink the role of education, adapting the competences of each and the different social groups, as a real right of citizenship. This European strategy is urgently needed at this point, through the Digital Education Action Plan but also by overcoming the current fragmentation. Above all, I share the awareness that today it is necessary that there is an adequate module, as within the PISA system, that can introduce mutual recognition between the various countries of digital skills in order to avoid even a digital divide that is deepening.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, it is the knowledge economy that will determine what happens in the years to come. It is a given that we need education, training, funds, so that society can really respond so that we do not create digital problems for our citizens. The most important thing is where the funds will be found. That's the main thing.  When you have the stability pact, which prohibits increased spending on public investment, then there is a serious problem. I believe, Commissioner, that the investment made by Member States in education, and in particular in digital technology training, should not count in the deficit. There we must have an exception, as well as there must be funds from the European Investment Bank, and also – especially for Greece – national funding should not be needed in order for Greece to enter the European programmes, as was the case with a special exception that has been in force for previous years.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the rapid development of technology has a direct impact on our daily lives, because it affects the way in which the various professions are carried out and these effects and this influence will last even more strongly in the future. This will also have an impact on jobs. Many jobs will be eliminated, others will be modified, others will be created. In order to survive in this environment of automation, digitisation and the rapid development of technology, every person must be trained in order to acquire the knowledge and skills that will enable him to survive in this environment. That is why all states and the European Union as a whole must plan their strategy and try to find the necessary funds so that they can educate their world in such a way that it can meet the demands of the modern age.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it is right that the European Union is responding to the rapid development of digital technologies, which are the engine of growth as well as employment. The problem is that the levels of development of digital technologies and citizens' skills are very different from one Member State to another, my pre-speechers have mentioned this. If, in the next 25 years, around half of the current jobs disappear and are replaced by jobs that require special digital skills, this is a challenge that both the Member States and, of course, the European Union as a whole must respond to. Above all, we must prepare teachers, equip schools with new devices and programs. But I also want to draw attention to the need to protect against digital abuse, cyber bullying, the spread of fake news, and also the need to educate critical thinking.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, digital skills are fast becoming central to all areas of life. This is true not only in the world of work, but also for administrative and social purposes. Quite simply, citizens with little or no access to digital education are at risk of being left behind. Digital literacy can no longer be treated as a luxury. It must be accessible to all as early as possible.  We must be bold in our ambitions and coherent in our approach by ensuring that sufficient funding is allocated. Digital education should be accessible in all areas – especially in rural areas – and provided equally to girls and women, as well as boys and men, in formal and informal settings.  Just last week we celebrated the week of lifelong learning, and I want to highlight the opportunities for early school leavers to benefit from digital education. Those people who are at high risk of unemployment and social exclusion must be especially targeted by policies aiming at mainstreaming digital skills, and I believe that here lies one of the keys towards providing equal opportunities for all.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament, and especially the honourable Member Yana Toom, for this high—quality report. Now that we are implementing the Digital Education Action Plan, your calls for a more ambitious EU strategy on education in the digital age come at the right moment.  As you rightly highlight, the Digital Education Action Plan, which the Commission published in early 2018, can only be a first step in tackling the digital divide. I strongly believe that Parliament can be a key partner in developing the next steps. I also believe that Member States are keen to cooperate more closely on this issue. Despite differences in their education systems, they all face similar challenges: first, how to ensure that staff and students develop digital skills; second, how to use digital technology for teaching and learning; and, third, how to improve education systems through better data analysis and foresight. This requires learning throughout one’s lifetime. Hence, digital competence is one of the eight key competences for lifelong learning that the Council confirmed in its recommendation adopted earlier this year. Member States are also working to embed digital technologies in the school environment. Investment in resources and infrastructure is crucial but, if it is to lead to innovation, it needs to be matched with a comprehensive vision for digital transformation that tackles the educational organisation as a whole. The Commission thinks that SELFIE, a free online tool just launched in October, can play a vital role here: it can help any school assess its use of technologies for teaching and learning. By the end of November, over 50 000 teachers, students and school leaders had already used SELFIE. Our goal is to reach one million users by the end of next year. I also welcome the emphasis on teachers and trainers in your report. I fully agree that teaching staff are at the heart of digital transformation. Teachers do of course need training, but crucially they need time and support to be able to use technology in their teaching. Technology should also help relieve teachers from the burden of administrative and non-teaching tasks. Moreover, in its proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the Commission has demonstrated commitment to supporting educators and learners in gaining and updating skills and competencies, including the digital ones. The EU budget support for digital skills development will not only be guaranteed by the successes of the existing EU funding instruments covering this field, such as ESF+, Erasmus and Horizon Europe, but also by the new Digital Europe programme. The Digital Europe programme will provide learning opportunities reflecting the latest technological developments in advanced digital skills relating to artificial intelligence, high—performance computing and cybersecurity.  As you rightly say in your report, all schools need to be provided with high capacity broadband. In fact, within the future Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) programme, after 2020 we aim to support access to Gigabit connectivity for socioeconomic drivers, including schools. With the future Digital Europe programme, in turn, we plan to support the deployment of digital capabilities in schools, and the future Erasmus programme will support schools, universities and other educational organisations in their digital transformation.  We therefore strongly welcome your support in the negotiation of these new programmes. I fully agree with the honourable Members that the Action Plan can only be the starting point of a broader debate. In keeping with the wishes of the Member States in Gothenburg, we deliberately started with schools, higher education and vocational education and training. Adult learning, non-formal education and teacher training will follow at the next stage. The plan has helped a great deal in generating political discussion and momentum, and we intend to build on this. To conclude, I would like to thank you again for this constructive discussion. The Commission looks forward to working with you in developing a fuller vision and strategy.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, December 11, 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. "Digitalisation is changing the world at a rapid pace. It affects jobs, for example, by reducing them from some sectors but by creating them in other areas. We constantly need more knowledge and skills to utilise technology, and many everyday things require sufficient IT know-how. Lifelong learning plays an important role in maintaining digital skills. It is not enough just to teach skills in schools, but opportunities to adopt digital skills must be offered to everyone, regardless of age and work situation. Libraries can play a big role in this.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – Digital and social skills are already becoming synonymous, so the lack of digital skills leads to a risk of social exclusion. Digital literacy statistics are ruthless for the European Union: currently 44% of the EU population aged 16-74 does not have basic digital skills and 19% have no digital skills at all, and the differences between Member States are very large. As a Representative of Lithuania to the EP, I can be proud that, in my Member State, questions about internet accessibility (and data speed) do not arise in principle – in this sense we are at the vanguard of Europe. However, it is important to constantly remind yourself that in the education system, the focus on the development of digital skills must undoubtedly be a priority. We are talking about this at EU level, which must be reflected in the agenda of each Member State. In the digital era, we are becoming increasingly vulnerable to threats related to cybersecurity vulnerabils, personal data breaches or fake news. The threats referred to must therefore receive due attention in the education system. I am sure that in the learning process, the perception of digital literacy should change from consumerism to digital technology to the ability to create digital content and form, as well as to critically assess what is created. Finally, the principle of lifelong learning in this case becomes particularly relevant in response to the challenges of the era of digitisation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Education has a vital role in our society, trainings and re-trainings should be available to everyone as it could be one of the best investments in the EU’s future. I totally agree that education is of strategic importance for employability, growth, competitiveness, innovation and social cohesion. However, digital transformation has a great impact on education systems just as much or even more than in other sectors. In the future, nearly all jobs, services as well as everyday activities, will require digital skills and data literacy; In the context of a rapid digital and societal transformation, the education system should support, from an early age and throughout life, a balanced set of skills and competences boosting individuals’ resilience, critical thinking, well-being, and innovation potential. Synergy between relevant digital skills, soft skills and hard skills needs to be sought as soon as possible. Furthermore, digital technology and access to data are enablers of innovation in education and open data is starting to become a very valuable educational resource. Digital transformation offers many opportunities for education and the economy. However, it needs a proper policy response. I highly support a strategy at EU level to develop such a response.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Giorgos Grammatikakis' report, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the new European Culture Agenda (2018/2091 (INI)) (A8-0388/2018).

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would first like to thank the shadow rapporteurs with whom I have had excellent cooperation. We have therefore come up with a text which I consider to be very important for culture in Europe. It is indeed a good coincidence that this text is being presented at the end of the European Year of Cultural Heritage, which highlighted the brilliance and importance of European culture. As I was drafting the report, I had in mind the multidimensional challenges facing Europe today: the economic crisis, the refugee issue, to the rise of populism and the far right. In these difficult times civilization can lead to the rediscovery of the common bonds that unite and connect us. In this context, therefore, we have worked in the Committee on Culture and have come up with concrete proposals, which move around three general axes: firstly, adequate funding for culture. It is necessary to at least double the Creative Europe programme. It is also necessary to create strong cooperation with the Structural and Investment European Funds, so that cultural actions reach 1% of the next budget. The truth, Madam President, highlighted by the great politician and orator of ancient Greece Demosthenes, "See money and without them any focus of the right", is as timely as ever.  Secondly, the protection of the rights of authors. It is well known that the nature of the authors' work often leads to economic uncertainty, and they often remain exposed to the interests of multinational giants. The adoption of the Copyright Directive last September was an important step in the right direction. But it must be completed and implemented as soon as possible and in the best possible way.  Thirdly, mobility of authors and their works. The European Union must make a decisive contribution to the mobility of creators in order to facilitate their contacts and enable them to reach the greatest possible audience, both within the Union and outside its borders.  In conclusion, I would like to refer to an innovative proposal, which other members of the Committee on Culture have strongly supported. It is the establishment of an institution which, in proportion to the European Capital of Culture, will bring out every year a personality that through its work and life has expressed and influenced European values. I could cite random but specific examples, such as Mozart, Leonardo da Vinci, Shakespeare, Plato, Goethe, Marie Curie and Simone de Beauvoir, Cervantes, so many others. Culture is expressed and flourished by people, and it is time for their contribution to be recognised at pan-European level.  In conclusion, Madam President, I would like to stress that the adoption of the report will, for the first time in many years, contribute to a coherent and coordinated path of culture for the Member States. It will be the best follow-up to the European Year of Cultural Heritage, which is coming out leaving behind its strong glow and deposits.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The new European Cultural Agenda and the report on it mention the importance of intercultural dialogue and ensuring intercultural interoperability. This issue is also crucial for national minorities in the European Union. Interculturalism presupposes reciprocity, interest in each other's cultures. Nevertheless, we find that in the countries in which we live, we are expected to know the majority culture, which is also found in compulsory curricula, in which the culture of national minorities is not included. Moreover, in Romania, hungarians are clearly present in a negative context in the compulsory curriculum currently in force. The culture, life and characteristics of the 1.3 million people in the country seem to exist as if they did not exist for the majority nation, as if they were not even happy to ignore us. Interculturalism does not mean this, and in addition to cooperation between states, it is also important to promote and promote the eddation of communities of different cultures in the same State.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Grammatikakis, very much for his excellent report and I am very happy that, eleven years after the previous European Agenda for Culture, the Commission - and I thank the Commissioner for this - has proposed a new strategy, i.e. a strategy, at last, of cultural policy that overcomes a situation of great fragmentation. I have to say that, in order to be a legislature that began with the word culture that did not exist in Juncker's ten priorities, thanks to the joint work between us and dg culture and education, we made a difference. Parliament has made a difference as has our committee. In the meantime, we are faced with an agenda that summarizes, at the end of the European Year of Cultural Heritage and, therefore, by helping the legacy of the year, summarizes the three or four main lines on which European cultural policy will have to move: that of the international strategy, with also the mobility of artists and cultural professionals at international level and therefore the promotion of intercultural and interreligious dialogue , the important issue of supporting the cultural and creative industries and, above all, that of horizontal integrated policies, which can also support the doubling of resources finally dedicated to culture.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I believe that the new European agenda for culture will be incomplete if a serious issue, which is the return of pruning archaeological treasures, is not resolved. As we go through the Year of Cultural Heritage, we cannot tolerate a situation where several – thousands I would say – cultural treasures, archaeological treasures cultural finds of Greece have been stolen by Nazi occupying troops and are illegally found in various museums in Germany. I have raised this issue on several occasions and I have called for the intervention of the European Commission, but it is not in its hands. We must realise that, if we want to have a real European agenda in culture, the European Parliament must call for the return of stolen archaeological treasures from Nazi occupying troops, a theft that took place in Greece and these treasures should be returned to Greece.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I think it is clear that the European Commission has great support for its cultural agenda from the Committee on Culture and Education. Not only is it proposing an increase in the Creative Europe programme, it is also proposing the establishment of a single point of contact for culture with regard to the European Union's financial programmes. We feel the need to support professionals and enable them to make these programs easier to access, easier to navigate and use. I myself would like to share a very fresh experience, because I had the opportunity to look into the international Visegrad project of students of four cities, the city of Krakow, Olomouc, Bratislava and Pécs. It is an ArtCoMe project and I can confirm that this activity is quite exceptional for students. It develops their knowledge, creativity and above all allows meeting and desire to cooperate and that is what we should be interested in.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this agenda is not only about jobs and the community, even though they’re important aspects of building a stronger and more open—minded Europe. We must also harness the power of culture and cultural diversity for social cohesion and wellbeing. We need to foster wider participation from diverse communities. We need to increase mobility for artists, and we must build on the excellent work done in the European Year of Cultural Heritage. We must embrace ‘STEAM’ instead of STEM. The A is for arts, which should be at the heart of all young people’s education.  Finally, a word about Brexit, which will be catastrophic for the UK’s creative and cultural industries: loss of freedom of movement and limited opportunities for collaboration will impoverish our nation economically and socially. But given the chaos in the British parliament, I’m still hoping that we can remain a member of the EU.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, thank you, first of all, also to the rapporteur. I am involved in stressing the importance of cultural heritage, which contributes to the strengthening of European identity. This cultural heritage shows that our ancestors have been united above national divisions and borders. Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance or Baroque are not national styles, but great artistic trends – even some would say philosophical – European. I am also thinking of the current European cultural routes and the first of them the roads of Santiago, as a testament to this European unity and identity. In taking care of Europe's cultural heritage, in preserving it, we also take care of the idea of Europe, we also take care of the process of European construction, as you well know, Commissioner. We must all contribute to the care and conservation of our cultural heritage, also the European Union. I will therefore read with the greatest attention the action plan recently submitted by the Commission. I would, of course, like an ambitious plan; I would even have liked a specific European programme or fund to help finance the tasks of recovery, reconstruction and conservation of European cultural heritage and thus make visible the special importance that this heritage also has for the institutions of the Union.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting discussion. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to congratulate Mr Grammatikakis on his excellent report on the new European Agenda for Culture. The Commission adopted the new Agenda for Culture as a response to EU leaders who, just about a year ago, had underlined the potential of culture as a means of creating a more inclusive and cohesive Europe. They therefore asked us to boost cooperation on culture at European level. I am proud to say that we, the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council, are delivering on this call. It is inspiring to see that we are all working towards the same objectives. In fact, last month, Member States adopted a new Council Work Plan for Culture 2019-2021. It contains over 30 measures, many of which coincide both with the Commission’s new agenda for culture and with the points made by Mr Grammatikakis in his report. Let me highlight some of them. First, together with the Member States, the Commission will leverage the power of culture to enhance social cohesion and to address the growing polarisation in European societies, a topic which is also highlighted in your report. Engaging with Europe’s culture promotes the inclusion of disadvantaged groups. Gender equality is a welcome new priority reflected in both the parliamentary report and the Council Work Plan. Second, it is excellent to have a measure for music in the Council Work Plan. With the support of the European Parliament, we have progressed on the Music Moves Europe initiative, and it is now time to bring this onto the policy level. Third, on international cultural relations, your report calls on the Commission to regularly update Parliament on the state of play of the initiatives we take to boost the role of culture in external relations. I am pleased to inform you that the Council has agreed to complete its work on an EU strategic approach to international cultural relations. The Commission and the European External Action Service are advancing their work on European Houses of Culture and on global cultural leadership training. Fourth, as your report makes clear, EU policymaking on culture is better if it is backed by providing financial support to the cultural and creative sectors. That is why the Commission’s proposal for a new Creative Europe programme after 2020 is fully aligned with our policy agenda, and proposes to increase funding. I am grateful for your support for the programme in general and on the key issue of the budget in particular. In line with your report, the new Agenda for Culture is a truly cross-cutting agenda, listing all EU funding opportunities available to cultural operators in fields as diverse as education, research, cohesion, the digital single market and external affairs.  Lastly, cultural heritage: a few days ago in Vienna, I presented the European Framework for Action on Cultural Heritage. The framework aims to ensure that the 2018 European Year of Cultural Heritage will have a lasting impact. You will be pleased to see that the framework addresses both tangible and intangible heritage, as emphasised in your report.  Honourable Members, let me thank you sincerely for your strong support for, and throughout, the European Year of Cultural Heritage. Together, we have made it happen. Together we can make it last beyond 2018. I believe that our new instruments will help us build more inclusive and cohesive societies and sustain our competitiveness, and, by doing so, they will invigorate the European project. The Commission looks forward to putting them into practice with you.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, December 11, 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – Culture plays an extremely important role in our societies and economies when it comes to creating a sense of belonging, promoting active citizenship and defining our identity and fundamental values of freedom, diversity, equality, solidarity and social justice. I support the New European Agenda for Culture Report, as all cultural and creative sectors should be provided with the same and tailor-made support focused on their specific challenges and cultural diversity and intercultural dialogue should be maintained as cross-sectoral priorities.  The new Cultural Agenda is an excellent opportunity to adopt a comprehensive and coherent cultural policy at European level that will be recognised by both European and non-EU citizens. However, it can only be successful if a much larger budget for creative Europe is envisaged, as well as the development of synergies and interactions with other Union-funded programmes, with a view to introducing a holistic, cross-sectoral approach to culture. The new Culture Agenda should provide a flexible framework for changing cultural ecosystems and fostering synergies between sectors.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The new European Agenda for Culture presented by the European Commission focuses on important cultural, social and economic aspects. The proposed actions in this area include general as well as concrete solutions and action plans. Many of the objectives of the new programme are worthy of support, including the development and creation of new jobs in the cultural and creative sectors, facilitating the mobility of artists, disseminating education in the fields of art and culture, promoting appropriate capacities and encouraging innovation. Unfortunately, the proposed text is more ideological, as well as incomprehensible European jargon and materialistic vision of culture than the promotion and protection of cultural heritage. Culture is the most important factor in shaping a sense of community, but it is worth supporting the heritage of European civilisation, provided that it is reflected in and does not break with the cultural heritage of nation states. It is necessary to expand access to culture as well as to strengthen relations between the societies of the Member States in order to fully exploit the potential of culture for sustainable development, but the proposed Commission's solutions and initiatives in most cases exceed the competences of the European Union, infringe the principle of subsidiarity and the exclusive competences of the Member States. The proposed solutions should aim at improving cooperation between countries as well as supporting government initiatives and local projects. International cultural relations should be strengthened rather than harmonised.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Internal Regulation).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, the Dăncilă Government is preparing to take over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. It's a deeply anti-European government. The one who runs it refused to work with the Commission. It recently announced that it would appeal the CVM report to the European Court of Justice. The Romanian Prime Minister also ignored the resolution that we recently adopted in this hemicycle, saying that it is an electoral gesture of the EPP and S&D, the group of which she has also been a part for ten years. The more than seventy ministers of the PSD-ALDE governments have a 15-20% presence in Council meetings. None of them have ever said anything good about the European Union. The deplorable quality of the current ministers and the anti-democratic drift of the socialist-liberal regime make the Union a stronger. The de facto-controlled government of Dragnea is not capable, neither intellectually nor politically, of assuming the presidency of the Council. I call for the urgent change of the Bucharest executive and the formation of a technical cabinet of experts on European issues and headed by one of the three Commissioners romania has sent over the past twelve years to the Barroso and Juncker colleges.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, on 2 December there was in Andalusia, a region of southern Spain with eight and a half million inhabitants, an election in which the news was no longer that the far right entered Parliament strongly; the news, today, is that Europeanist, Democratic and constitutionalist parties intend or are willing to join with that far right to reach the government. In democracy we can clearly say that not everything is worth it. This was done by Mr Verhofstadt to his counterpart, but we have not yet heard Mr Weber say the same thing. On 26 May we will have elections to the European Parliament and it is not enough to say that the wolf is coming, we must fight it. And the wolf, as I say, is here. And The Europeanist groups, which declare themselves Europeanists, have to reaffirm the rules of the game, and the rules are the defence of tolerance, fundamental rights, freedom, equality and this Europe that the far right wants to destroy. This Parliament must therefore give its opinion now and especially in view of the forthcoming May elections.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the afternoon, Parliament rejected the ECR's request to hold a debate on the situation in France and the threats to democracy in the country.  The whole of Europe and the whole world are following with concern the events in France, rape scenes reminiscent of almost civil war. This parliament has decided that it is better not to talk about it. However, he recently applauded President Marcon for his recent lashings of applause, confirming how much he does not understand the current political situation in his majority. But by its double standards it pours oil into the fire. As one Polish think tank, the Centre for Political Thought, aptly wrote on Twitter: "There are no double standards for its members in the Union. There are quadruple standards: firstly, for the largest states of the "old Union", secondly, for the rest of the "old Union", thirdly, for a "new Union" ruled by parties from the PPE faction, liberals or socialists and, finally, for a "new Union" ruled by someone outside those factions." This Union of quadruple standards has no future ahead of it and is unful of the Europe for which it likes to serve.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, I’ve been standing here many times defending Kosovo and Kosovars on their way to the European Union, believing the decisions taken by the government to have been mostly right, but this time I simply cannot do it. The decision to take 100% tariffs on the neighbouring countries, Serbia and Bosnia Herzegovina, is just catastrophic. It will hurt the neighbouring countries’ economies, it will hurt the Kosovan economy, and it will result in the loss of friends in the European Union for Kosovo. That’s why this decision has to be revoked immediately, because we need it for the sake of the region, for the needs of the country, and for the sake of European unity and Europe’s friend Kosovo.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, the murder in Chile of The Mapuche community Camilo Catrillanca demonstrates the failure of repression as a way to resolve the conflict in the region; a conflict where land is key. Militarization and violence are due to a model of deposesion of Mapuche territories in favour of forestry, mining and hydroelectric. Carabinieri protect entrepreneurs and attack communities that oppose the occupation of their lands. Camilo, before his death, had already been monitored by the police for his defense of Mapuche cultural identity. Your community is the most active in defending the territory. We demand that these facts be clarified and given to its leaders. If the State does not respond to the historical demands of the Mapuche people for reparation and recognition, there will be no peace, civil coexistence and progress in the region. All our support from here, from the European Parliament, and our solidarity with the Mapuche people.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, while today we are celebrating the anniversary of human rights, the Mediterranean is left without life-saving boats. How much we have to thank Aquarius because human rights were not just paper. Human rights is to rescue the weakest. Human rights is to combat the advance of neo-fascism in the world and in Europe. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights enshrines common values and principles and neo-fascism is contrary to them, because fascist ideology and intolerance attack democracy itself. I am very good that on 25 October we gave this Parliament a sign of bravery. The European Parliament has voted against the impunity enjoyed by neo-fascist and neo-Nazi groups in Europe, but we are alert against street fascism, the digital of fake news and the institutional one, such as vox in Spain, such as that of the Francisco Franco Foundation. Since that day, 25 October, we have in Europe new reports of fascist attacks, one also in my country.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, it is exactly 70 years since the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was signed in Paris. I would like to recall that, under the leadership of the former First Lady of the United States of America, Eleanor Roosevelt, representatives of Europe, America and Asia, in particular the still non-communist China, Were working on it, Mr Chang. The text of the declaration greatly influenced and made it acceptable to china at the time. Seventy years on, the situation has changed. While China does not respect human rights in its country, countries that have emuded from the communist dictatorship and joined the European Union have embraced these rights. But it is not won anywhere in the world or in advanced Europe. I therefore welcome the petition initiated by ADF International for life, family and religious freedom. Forty-five thousand people have already signed this petition, and I call for it to be signed. Addressed to the UN, the petition reads: "We call on all nations of the world to respect the fundamental human rights to life, family and religious freedom recognised by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights." It is time to support this petition.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the second part of this year has brought with it a number of social movements in several European countries. The "yellow vest" demonstrations in France are increasingly present in several Western European states.  About two months ago, in a resolution, the European Parliament condemned the Romanian government and law enforcement in Bucharest for the intervention necessary to restore order. In this context, and rightly so now, after at least as harsh interventions by the French or Belgian gendarmes, some of my compatriots wonder why the European Parliament does not have the same kind of approach. Double-acting behaviour and biased attitude in dealing with similar cases risks becoming one of the factors that undermine the germs of Europeans' distrust of the European project, in the European institutions, which both Parliament and the European Commission should reflect on for a long time and take appropriate measures, the same for all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I come back to the question of the suppression of the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent for the umpteenth time, because Rama and his group continue their policy of ethnic cleansing. In practice, it wants to drive the minority, the North Continentals, out of their ancestral homes, and that is why it is trying to alter the population characteristics. It transports to the area of Kosovar, does not allow the Greek language to be taught in schools. And yet all these are guaranteed rights from the famous Corfu Protocol of 1914, which gives autonomy to the North Continent. The policy of persecution continues and Rama, his company and the Albanian police ended up executing Konstantinos Katsifas, and not only that, but the day before that he did not even allow the memorial service to take place. Disgrace!

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, just last week we held a screening of The Ballymurphy Precedent in the European Parliament in Brussels. I want to commend the courage, determination and tenacity of the Ballymurphy families whose loved ones were shot dead over three days by members of the British army in August 1971. The massacre in Ballymurphy, carried out by the British Parachute Regiment, came just five months prior to the murder by the same regiment of 14 Civil Rights marchers in my home town of Derry on Bloody Sunday.  This is an incredibly difficult time for the Ballymurphy families who are currently engaged on a daily basis with the long-awaited inquest into the murder of their loved ones. The Coroner, Justice Keenan, condemned the British Ministry of Defence, stating that the nature of the information coming forward was not acceptable. However, the British Defence Secretary, Gavin Williamson, has set up a new legal expert unit to prevent members of the British forces from facing the court. There should be no immunity or impunity for British soldiers guilty of crimes of collusion or murder in Ireland.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, today was International Human Rights Day. You know what this is? (The speaker displays a book). This is a compilation of stories that Oriol Junqueras, a former MEMBER in this House, has written to his children. He had to write them from prison, where he's been in prison for 403 days, on re-trial detention, for organising a referendum so we could vote. Oriol has seen his sons Lluc and Joana in a 36-hour year, or what is the same, Lluc and Joana have seen their father—who is a person who has always been committed to democracy, justice and dignity—just a day and a half. Are we talking about human rights today, which is International Human Rights Day? Are we talking about the nine Catalan political prisoners, four of them on hunger strike? The complicit silence of the institutions of the European Union with what is happening in Catalonia is a sign of weakness and hypocrisy. We real Europeanists don't look the other way. True Europeanists defend fundamental rights always and everywhere. Also today and also in the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, we are getting christmas holidays, which should be holidays of peace and tranquility. On the other hand, we would all like to experience them in the family circle, perhaps even at Christmas markets or public gatherings, but especially in peace and security. I think that security is really key. After the attacks that took place just for the Christmas holidays in Germany, we need to be sure that radicalised groups are actually eliminated. On the contrary, we are getting rather more worrying news from a number of European countries. I think the issue of lack of coordination between intelligence services, security forces that do not share information with each other, is coming to the fore.  What do the citizens of the European Union expect? They undoubtedly expect protection and safety. If there are trust issues between these security forces, I think it is important to name them, not publicly, but certainly to address them so that we do not see the terrible events that took place a few years ago again for the Christmas holidays. Let me conclude on Human Rights Day by congratulating Karel Schwarzenberg, the prominent former Czech Foreign Minister, who is having his birthday today.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the yellow vest protest in France is a symptom of the disease, but is not the disease itself. This is the distrust of Europeans in their political elite. The symptoms suggest that the authorities and residents of the country have a different understanding of their problems. According to recent polls, only 20—25% of French residents trust President Emmanuel Macron, and over 70% do not trust him. When Macron was elected as President two years ago, many people had the impression that they had voted for liberal values and a united Europe. However, few people paid attention to the fact that Macron received support not for his views, but rather for the fact that he was the only candidate in the elections who was fresh and did not belong to the old political elite. People gave him a mandate of trust, but time was spent on euphoria and false promises. It’s necessary to start a real dialogue.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I convey to the European Parliament the cry of anguish and despair of the Greeks of the North Continent, from whom the brutal, corrupt, fascist Albanian regime deprives all human rights. He terrorizes them, arrests them, interrogates them harshly and imprisons them. He's deporting journalists and other civilians. It prevents them from speaking the Greek language and performing their religious duties as Christians. In schools, the teaching of the Greek language is forbidden and the property of the Greeks is arbitrarily and illegally taken over by the government and given to settlers, who are transferred en masse to alter the demographic composition of the population and force the Greeks to leave their place. Today humanity commemorates World Human Rights Day, but few know what is happening in the North Continent. I call on the European Parliament to speed up the sending of an ad hoc committee to investigate the inhumane conditions in which thousands of Greeks live at home.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Madam President, seventy years ago, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted, which is inseparable and belongs to every person according to both natural and Divine law.  This declaration is one of the foundations on which our world has been restored after the most horrific war. It is important to go back to it, to learn to understand and respect it properly.  We're not going to find the right to an abortion, just the right to life. Nevertheless, today we who refuse to perform abortions are accused of not respecting a woman's right, while the right of the unborn child to life is called into question. And Christians who exercise the right of conscience are criticised by part of society.  If we deny the right to life to an unborn child, we will question life as absolute value. And a society that does not respect every human life will sooner or later become inhumane. Let's not forget that.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: –Madam President, in less than a month, twelve years after joining the European Union, Romania will take over the Presidency of the Council of the Union. For my country, this is a historic moment, which crowns a period from accession to the Union to today. We are talking about another historic moment, after Romania celebrated the centenary this year. The mandate before my country is a difficult one, which is why I welcome the message of the President of the European Commission, Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, who appreciated that my country is ready to carry out this mission. I am convinced that Romania will carry out this task with flying colors. I call on all fellow MEPs from all political groups to support the report on Romania and Bulgaria's accession to the Schengen area. Cohesion within the European Union needs to grow, and this cannot be achieved, realistically, if some Member States have fewer rights than others.  I ask in solidarity from all the Member States of the European Union to support the achievement of such legitimate objectives, both for the management of the dossiers and for the period during which Romania will hold the Presidency of the Council of the European Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed.
